headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Pall Corporation's conference call and webcast for the fourth quarter and year end for fiscal 2010. Today's call is being recorded and simultaneously webcast. Instructions for the question-and-answer session will be provided at the end of manag
componenttext:
Welcome to Pall Corporation's conference call and webcast for the fourth quarter and year end for fiscal 2010. Today's call is being recorded and simultaneously webcast. Instructions for the question-and-answer session will be provided at the end of management's prepared remarks. Right now, all lines are in a listen-only mode.
We would like to remind you that the company's fourth quarter and year end press release is available at www.pall.com. Management's remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements. Please refer to slide two or request a copy of the specific wording of this qualification of the company's remarks.
Management also uses certain non-GAAP measures to assess the company's performance. Reconciliations of these measures to their GAAP counterparts are included in the slides at the end of the presentation.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Eric Krasnoff, Pall Corporation's Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer and Frank Moschella, Corporate Controller.In
componenttext:
Thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer and Frank Moschella, Corporate Controller.
In addition to reviewing the fourth quarter's performance and recapping the year, we will also be providing guidance for fiscal year 2011. We look forward to your questions at the end of our prepared remarks.
As reported last evening, Pall posted a solid fourth quarter and saw an upturn in momentum for the second half of the fiscal year. Through judicious cost management, we position Pall to benefit as business conditions improved and we continued to invest and focus on our growth strategies, new products, markets, applications and regions.
Pall announced ambitious performance goals for fiscal '10 last December. Lisa will discuss key drivers in detail a little later. The bottom line, pro forma EPS of $2.12 was within our original guidance of $2.02 to $2.19 and it was the high end excluding foreign exchange.
Given better than expected performance in the fourth quarter, principally in BioPharmaceuticals, Microelectronics and Machinery and Equipment, EPS exceeded the high end of the guidance we provided after the second quarter. Operating cash flows came in at $378 million compared to our high end estimate of $365 million.
Life Sciences performed well all year, particularly in the key BioPharmaceuticals market which grew over 10% in local currency. Our Industrial business finished the year with sales down 3%. The global recession and consequent drop in Industrial Manufacturing activity slowly abated as our year progressed.
The effect of capital spending is still being felt in our systems business where the order to shipment cycle can be as long as two years. At mid-year, Microelectronics rebounded and Other sectors began to stir. Industrial turned positive again beginning in the third quarter on the strength of a handful of markets and the remaining markets are now also setting up to grow again.
Total orders grew 19% in the fourth quarter. Focusing in on Pall Industrial, their orders grew 26% over last year's Q4 with all Industrial markets contributing. This follows a 54% increase in orders for Industrial in the third quarter. Now, staying with Industrial, orders for consumables grew 38%, following on 42% increase in Q3. This reflects increasing customer capacity utilization, some inventory restocking and a revival of customer appetite for capital expenditure.
Positive for the year was the improvement in gross margin. It came in at just above 50%. Those of you who have following us know that we’ve been shipping away at cost of sales.
We were gratified to see this heavy lifting of reducing our manufacturing footprint and showing a lean culture, improving margins on systems and implementing our pricing excellence program, not just to offset the effects of the weak economy as they did in 2009 but enabled us to leverage in improving top line in the second half of fiscal '10.
Before I hand off to Lisa, I'll run down Q4 results by market and give an indication of what we're seeing as we enter our new year. As you saw in the press release last evening, we’ve made several organizational changes to better manage the business. These changes are illustrated on slide six.
Pall year-over-year comparisons are on a restated basis and the discussion on sales and orders is in local currency unless otherwise stated. Fourth quarter sales came in at $679 million and this is up 4% over last year on an as reported basis. Currency turned from favorable for much of the year to a headwind.
Sales grew 6% overall with Life Science up over 7.5% and Industrial positive for the second quarter in a row, growing 4%. Sales in the Western hemisphere increased 14% with Industrial markets leading at a 20% growth. Europe was down close to 3% on weakness of several Industrial markets and Asia overall grew 10%.
Let's look at the details starting with Life Sciences. BioPharmaceuticals now represents a quarter of Pall's total sales. It's been a steady contributor. In the fourth quarter, we saw a 10% increase in both consumables and system sales as all regions grew. Some of the key drivers, increased production of filtration intensive biotech drugs, the vaccine market is remaining strong, the market for single use technologies is expanding and emerging markets are beginning to move the needle.
In short order, China has become the third largest market for drugs in the world. Consumables sales in Asia grew 10% in the year even though Japan Pall's largest Asian country was flat. Q4 orders increased over 17% and systems orders increased over 100% as capital spending has come back in this market. We enter fiscal year '11 with a strong backlog, up almost 30%.
Turning to medical, they had a very good closing quarter with sales up 3.6%. The blood and critical care markets performed. Blood filter sales increased over 3% despite the continuing trend of reduced collections in the U.S. New products here are playing a key role.
Hospital critical care had a good quarter with sales up 8%. Sales in Europe were also up about 8% with a market for water filters since lodging. And sales in Asia were up sharply. New products, as I mentioned before, are key to medical's growth and about 30% of our sales for the year came from recently introduced products. These higher margin products continue to make medical a strong contributor to Life Science's profit growth in the quarter. Q4 orders increased almost 6%.
Looking now at Food and Beverage which has moved from Industrial and was integrated within the Life Sciences business, in the quarter it also returned to growth. Sales were up over 8% in all regions - with all regions contributing, that is, consumable sales, a reflection of increasing production, increased about 5.5%.
System sales nearly doubled in Food and Beverage from the third quarter to the fourth, reflecting improving orders starting in the second quarter. Q4 orders for both consumables and systems increased double digits and we enter fiscal '11 with a backlog that's up 34% over fiscal '09.
Now let's switch gears for a review of Pall Industrial which after a challenging start began to grow in the second half, much of this growth driven by the return of Microelectronics. Other markets remain spotty with pockets of market and geographic strength.
Orders increased 26% in the quarter and became widespread and the entering backlog for Industrial is $465 million, an increase of 28% again over fiscal '09.
Now, looking at the markets, Energy and Water which was 20% of Pall sales in 2010 now consists of three submarkets, fuels and chemicals, the largest of the three, power generation and municipal water. These markets share common imperatives for high yields for protecting assets worth hundreds of millions of dollar in each plant and meeting increasingly stringent environmental regs.
Total sales with capital equipment in these markets can be large, lumpy and long term. Results today can reflect orders as long as two years ago. Such is the case in fuels and chemicals where sales decreased 11% in the quarter, reflecting reduced capital orders earlier.
Good news here is that the base business has grown 5% after four quarters of double-digit declines. This reflects increasing production particularly in Asia and the Middle East. Orders increased 6% in Q4 on top of 84% growth in Q3. The large increase in the third quarter includes Tecnimont job we recently announced.
The backlog in fuels and chemicals currently exceeds $100 million, an increase of more than 24% over last year. Power generation was down 13% in the quarter, but a bright spot of late has been the rapid expansion of the wind turbine market in China and Pall's share has been growing dramatically.
Looking ahead, Q4 orders in Power Gen picked up over 40% with base orders including housing increasing 50%. Systems orders increased 7% and these orders for housing and systems forecast a growing customer confidence and future demand for energy. Overall, the backlog in Pall Energy exceeds $165 million, which is up 28% over fiscal '09.
Let's move on to municipal Water. This market grew 7% in the quarter driven by 57% increase in the Western hemisphere. The municipal water market is for now a U.S. centric although the opportunity is decidedly global.
U.S. market remains strong as municipalities continue to upgrade membrane filtrations until membrane filtrations comply with EPA regulations. U.S. orders almost doubled compared to this time last year and project activity is accelerating in Asia.
We entered fiscal 2011 with $100 million backlog in muni water, which is more than 30% over 2009. This is our highest ever in this market.
Aeropower now comprised of Aerospace and Machinery and Equipment markets represents 17% of total Pall sales in 2010. Aerospace and Machinery and Equipment are roughly the same size. And overall this Aeropower market grew 4% in the quarter as M&A grew 28% and is now approaching 2008 levels.
Mining, steel and automotive productions are good examples of markets driving current results. Aerospace was down 14% compared to Q4 '09. It did improve sequentially. Commercial aero was up slightly after four down quarters and military aero was down as expected.
Aeropower orders increased almost 50% with both markets, that is Aerospace and Machinery and Equipment growing above 50%. All submarkets and regions also contributed and the backlog in Aeropower is up 18% over the fiscal '09 numbers.
Now, finally, let's go to Microelectronics. Microelectronics finished the fourth quarter, up over 35% in sales and 20% for the year, outperforming our full year expectations. The market is being driven by near full utilization rates at chip manufacturers and improving consumer appetite for electronic products.
Recovery is in full swing here and all regions in key segments of this diverse market are participating from chip production to the OEMs that supply the industry, consumer electronics such as flat panel display, printers and new opportunities including the emerging high bright LED market.
Growth in MicroE shows no signs of abating based on our current order book and Q4 orders increased 33%. Now with that, let me have Lisa review the financial details.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Good morning everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011. Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share, compared
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Good morning everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011. Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share, compared to $69.5 million or $0.58 per share last year.
Pro forma earnings per share as defined on slide 22 were $0.72 compared to $0.57 per share, an increase of 26%. Net earnings for the full year were $241.2 million or $2.03 per share, compared to $195.6 million or $1.64 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share were $2.12, compared to $1.77 a year ago, an increase of 20%.
Foreign currency translation did not impact earnings per share in the quarter, while an increased earnings per share by $0.10 for the full year. Sales increased 4% in the quarter. Foreign currency translation decreased the top line by about $12 million or 2%. This was primarily due to the weakening of the Euro and to a lesser extent the British pound against the dollar.
The strength of the Japanese yen and several other Asian currencies probably offset this. Excluding this impact, sales were up 6% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2009, reflecting an 8% increase in consumables and a 6% decrease in systems.
Sales increased 3% for the year. Foreign currency translation added about $58 million or 2.5% to our top line. This was primarily the result of a weakening dollar against most Asian currencies, the Euro and Canadian dollar. Excluding this impact, sales were up slightly in the year compared to fiscal year 2009. This reflects a 3% increase in consumables with a 15% decrease in systems.
Pricing gains in Life Sciences and Industrial contributed approximately $5 million in the quarter and approximately $12 million in Life Sciences partly offset by decline in Industrial for the full year. Gross margins in the fourth quarter improved 370 basis points to 49.8% with contributions from both businesses. Pall Industrial's gross margins came - excuse me - in at 47.8% up 570 basis points year-over-year.
Key drivers noted in our third quarter continued into the fourth quarter. Volume increases in high margin markets positively impacting mix and overhead absorption, as well as cost savings outpacing inflationary items. Life Sciences gross margins also improved year-over-year coming in at 59.1% up 160 basis points. This reflects continued pricing improvement and manufacturing cost reductions. The decline from the third quarter is principally attributable to mix.
SG&A was 27.8% of sales in the fourth quarter, down from 30% in the third quarter. Year-over-year SG&A increased 5% excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. And for the year, SG&A increased by 3.5% excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. Majority of this increase relates to investments we're making to drive sales up and SG&A down. These include the costs of the European management center, the implementation of our global ERP system and investments in selling and marketing costs principally in emerging region. The remainder is attributable to inflation being largely offset by cost reductions.
Turning to income taxes, the effective tax rate or as reported tax rate for the year was 26.4%. Excluding items that we do not consider to be recurring and therefore do not include in the calculation of pro-forma earnings per share, Pall's underlying tax rate for the year was 31% favorable to the 31.3% forecasted for the year. Net interest expense in Europe reflects the benefit of reversing interest accrued of approximately $11 million, primarily related to the resolution of certain foreign tax audits, excluding these items net interest expense decreased by $2 million.
Turning now to cash flow, operating cash flow in the year was $378 million, compared to $327 million last year, an increase of over 50 million or about 15%. This reflects improvements in working capital management, particularly accounts payable terms, resulting in a reduction of our cash conversion cycle of about 13 days. This was offset by increased taxes paid and pension funding.
Other significant uses of cash during the year included $136 million in capital spending reflecting increased investment in our IT infrastructure and wrapping up our headquarters renovation, $100 million to purchase 2.7 million shares of the company's common stock, leaving approximately $350 million on our current authorization. This represents the repurchase of $345 million cumulatively for the three years ended July 31st, 2010 decreasing our shares outstanding by over 10 million. $71million in dividends to shareholders, a 10% increase year-over-year and $18.5 million for the acquisition of biotechnology company and certain distribution rights.
The cash position stood at just under $500 million at July 31st, 2010 and our net debt to net debt plus equity was 19.4, down from 21.4 at July 31st, 2009. Indebtedness at July 31st, 2010 reflects the previously disclosed public offering of $375, 5% senior notes due June 15th, 2010 as well as outstandings on our new five year revolving credit facility of about $250 million. These transactions further secure Pall's liquidity for years to come and enhance our operational flexibility.
The timing was optimal, given historically low interest rates and the abundance of credit. We just closed the books on a year of achievement and the second year of Pall's 2013 strategic plan. For those of you who are new to Pall, we updated this plan last December. You can find the plan details on the IR branch of our website. While this plan has many elements, the ultimate measure of success will be in two numbers, Pall's earnings per share and cash flow generation by the end of fiscal 2013.
I'm pleased to report that Pall's results for 2010 in these two critical measures put us on track to meeting our goals under the strategic plan. Let's look at the significant drivers. Sales were slightly below the low single digit growth in local currency expectation for the year. Sales growth in Life Sciences was on plan, while Industrial sales decline of 3% for the year was below. Obtaining price increases in the Industrial economic environment was challenging, although we hired plan there the Pall Industrial sales organization is very focused on this.
As Eric mentioned, crossing the 50% gross margin milestone was significant. This was a 290 basis point step-up and was ahead of plan. Beneficial mix from the outperforming growth of pharmaceuticals and microelectronics consumable sales, as well as cost savings and manufacturing are the highlights for the year. SG&A as at 30.8% of sales is slightly behind plan reflecting the strategic investments we're making.
Life Sciences operating margin of 22.6% is on plan, while Industrial's operating margin of 14.1% is ahead of plan on higher than expected gross margins in the back half of the year mitigating the shortfall. Overall EBIT margin of 16.3% is ahead of plan and earnings per share of $2.12 were at the high end of our expectations, excluding the headwind of foreign currency translation. We are on track with our cash flow and working capital management objective.
Looking at 2011, we expect local currency sales growth of mid to high single digits in both Life Sciences and Industrial. This is tracking to the plan. At current rates, we expect foreign currency translation to be about 1% negative to revenue. By market we expect medical to improve to low single digit growth. We expect high single digit growth in biopharmaceuticals and for phoned beverage to grow mid-single-digits.
In Industrial, we expect the energy market to grow at mid-single-digit and water which will be primarily systems to grow double digits for overall growth in energy and water of mid single digits. We expect Aerospace to deliver high single to low double-digit growth and machinery and equipment to grow by mid single digits, for overall Aeropower translates to mid to high single digit growth.
And finally, we expect microelectronics growth to stabilize at high single digit growth for the year. Gross margins are estimated to be in the range of 50% to 51% which continues to be ahead of plan. Pricing, volume and continued manufacturing efficiencies should be partly offset by mix headwinds as systems and lower margin markets are expected to recover.
SG&A is forecasted to be about 30.5% of sales and although this is behind plan we expect the investments we're making in the early years of the plan to drive SG&A as well as operational costs down in the out years. That said expected EBIT margins of 16% to 17% are on track for the plan. The forecasted underlying income tax rate for 2011 is approximately 27%, which is a 4% reduction in the rate year-over-year as we achieved the August 1st go live for our European headquarters on schedule.
Pro forma earnings per share is expected to be in the range of $2.35 and $2.55 and includes an approximate $0.03 headwind from foreign currency translation compared to 2010, this is a $0.10 reduction compared to the December 2009 exchange rate used for the plan.
Excluding this, earnings per share is tracking to the plan. Operating cash flow was expected to be in the range of $435 million to $460 million and capital expenditures are expected to increase to $165 million to $175 million, as we continue to invest in our IT infrastructure and manufacturing capabilities. We have many levers to employ to achieve our earnings per share and cash flow goals for 2013. The bottom line is this. Pall's 2010 results have us on track to achieve them and our expectations for 2011 keep us there.
Thank you for your attention this morning. And with that I'll hand this back to Eric.

componenttext: If we look at the Life Sciences side, really as a whole I think we expect to see a continuation of the last few years with emerging markets contributing more and more to the Life Science pot, if you will. On the Industrial side, we believe that microelectronics will start to slow again in the second half of our new fiscal year. We're looking of course at easy comps but for Aeropower overall to recover very nicely this year and the whole energy and in Water area we see a good order trend there and not just stability but reinvestment again in new energy sources, alternative energy. Geographically, the out-liar has been Europe. Europe is particularly weak and especially weak in Industrial for 2010. There, we do see some good signs of life in Germany and I think overall for the European economies. And again, it's been borne out by our August results where orders were quite strong.

componenttext: Good morning. I had a couple of quick questions. I was hoping to get a little bit more clarity on the Life Sciences market in terms of what's driving more of the growth between vaccine and drugs? Do you see more plants coming on in the vaccine segment or drug segment? And then secondly, if you could comment on the replacement market for the muni business and then lastly, a couple of quick specifics on your lean initiatives for 2011.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think what we’ve seen in vaccine is more capacity being added as well as more approvals for vaccines, plus new vaccines or vaccines that are new to those countries where they're being approved for use. As far as the - the other driver of course is the
componenttext:
I think what we’ve seen in vaccine is more capacity being added as well as more approvals for vaccines, plus new vaccines or vaccines that are new to those countries where they're being approved for use. As far as the - the other driver of course is the move toward single use disposables in biotechnology for cell growth and both of those are strong. The larger one obviously is the biotech, additional capacity.
On the muni market, the replacement business continues steady. It's a very - still a relatively low number because the Municipal Water of - our products last - they can last up to eight years, but we are seeing a steady uptick as the volume of in place or embedded products from Pall grows from year-to-year, if we look at that eight year back horizon. And your third question?

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010

componenttext: I was hoping for a couple specific examples in your lean initiatives in terms of low hanging fruit for 2011.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, one good example will be the supply chain, where now with as you know we have our Chief Operating Officer, Roberto Perez is responsible for both Industrial and Life Science and while we are very much committed to maintaining two distinct, separate s
componenttext: Well, one good example will be the supply chain, where now with as you know we have our Chief Operating Officer, Roberto Perez is responsible for both Industrial and Life Science and while we are very much committed to maintaining two distinct, separate strong lines of business, we are looking for areas where we can better integrate them and supply chain is an obvious one, collapsing distribution, centralization of the use of, for freight, as examples. And really get at some of our inventory turn issues. That’s for freight.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010

componenttext: Hi. Thanks for taking the question. Two questions. For Life Sciences, backlog tends to not be as meaningful because orders ships pretty quickly.

Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Cont
componenttext:
Well, thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Controller.
Now in addition to reviewing the fourth quarter's performance and recapping the year, we will also be providing guidance for our fiscal year 2011. We look forward to your questions at the end of our prepared remarks. As reported last evening, Pall posted a solid fourth quarter and so an upturn in momentum for the second half of the fiscal year. 
Through a judicious cost management, we position Pall to benefit as business conditions improve and we continue to invest and focus on our growth strategy, new products, market applications and regions. Pall announced the ambitious performance goals for fiscal '10 last December. Lisa will discuss key drivers with some detail a little later. The bottom line, pro forma EPS of $2.12 was within our original guidance of $2.02 to $2.19 and was at the high end, excluding foreign exchange. 
Given better-than-expected performance in the fourth quarter, principally in BioPharmaceuticals, Microelectronics and Machinery & Equipment, EPS exceeded the high end of the guidance we provided after the second quarter. Operating cash flows came in at $378 million compared to our high-end estimate of $365 million. 
Life Sciences performed well all year, particularly in the key BioPharmaceuticals market, which grew over 10% in local currency. Our Industrial business finished the year with sales down 3%. The global recession and consequent drop in industrial manufacturing activity slowly abated as our year progressed. The effect of scant capital spending is still being felt in our Systems business where the order-to-shipment cycle can be as long as two years. At midyear, Microelectronics rebounded and other sectors began to stir. Industrial turned positive again beginning in the third quarter on the strength of a handful of markets and the remaining markets are now also setting up to grow again.
Total orders grew 19% on the fourth quarter, our focusing in on Pall Industrial, their orders grew 26% over last year's Q4, with all Industrial markets contributing. This follows a 54% increase in orders for Industrial in the third quarter. 
Now staying with Industrial, orders for consumables grew 38% following on a 42% increase in Q3. This reflects increase in customer capacity utilization, some inventory restocking and a revival of customer advertisement capital expenditure. 
A positive for the year was the improvement in gross margin that came in at just above 50%. Those of you who have been following us know that we've been chipping away our cost of sales. We were gratified to see this heavy lifting of reducing our manufacturing footprint and instilling a lean culture, improving margins on systems and implementing our pricing excellence program not just to offset the effects of a weak economy as they did in 2009 but enable us to leverage improving top line in the second half of fiscal '10. 
Before I hand off to Lisa, I'll run down Q4 results by market and give an indication of what we're seeing as we enter our new year. As you saw in the press release last evening, we've made several organizational changes to better manage the business. These changes are illustrated on Slide 6. All year-over-year comparisons are on a restated basis and the discussion on sales and orders with the local currency unless otherwise stated.
Fourth quarter sales came at $679 million and this is up 4% over last year on an as-reported basis. Currency turned from favorable for months of the year to a headwind. Sales grew 6% overall with Life Science, up over 7.5% and Industrial, positive for the second quarter in a row, growing 4%. Sales in the Western Hemisphere increased 14%, with Industrial markets leading at a 20% growth. Europe was down close to 3%, on weakness in several Industrial markets, and Asia overall grew 10%. 
Let's look at the details starting with Life Sciences. BioPharmaceuticals now represent a quarter of Pall's total sales. It's been a steady contributor. In the fourth quarter, we saw a 10% increase in both consumables and system sales and all regions grew. Some of the key drivers: increased production and filtration of in terms of biotech drugs, the vaccine remarket is remaining strong market, the market for single-use technologies is expanding and emerging markets are beginning to move the needle. 
In short order, China has become the third largest market for drugs in the world. Consumable sales in Asia grew 10% in the year, even though Japan, the most largest Asian country, was flat. Q4 orders increased over 17% and systems orders increased over 100% as capital spending has come back in this market. We entered fiscal year '11 with a strong backlog, up almost 30%.
Turning to Medical. They had a very good closing quarter with sales up 3.6%. The Blood in critical care markets performed. Blood filter sales increased over 3% despite the continuing trend of reduced collections in the U.S. New products here are playing a key role. Hospital critical care had a good quarter with sales up 8%. Sales in Europe were also up about 8%, with the market for water filters as largest and sales in Asia were up sharply. 
New products, as I mentioned before, are key to Medical's growth and about 30% of our sales for the year came from recently introduced products. These higher margin products continue to make Medical a strong contributor to Life Sciences profit growth in the quarter. Q4 orders increased almost 6%.
Now at Food and Beverage, which has moved from Industrial and was integrated within the Life Science business, in the quarter, it had also returned to growth. Sales were up over 8% in all regions, with all regions contributing, that is. Consumable sales, a reflection of increasing production increased about 5.5%. System sales nearly doubled in Food and Beverage from the third quarter to the fourth, reflecting improving orders starting in the second quarter. Q4 orders for both consumables and systems increased double digits, and we enter fiscal '11 with a backlog that's up 34% over fiscal '09.
Now I'll swith gears for a review of Pall Industrial, which after a challenging start began to grow in the second half. Much of this growth was driven by the return of Microelectronics. Other markets remain spotty with the pockets of market in geographic strength. Orders increased 26% in the quarter and became widespread. And the entry backlog for Industrial is $465 million, an increase of 28%, again over fiscal '09. 
Now looking at the markets, Energy & Water, which was 20% of Pall's sales in 2010, now consists of three submarkets: Fuels and Chemicals, the largest of the three; Power Generation; and Municipal Water. These market share common imperatives for high yields for protecting assets worth hundreds of million of dollars in each plant and meeting increasingly stringent environmental regs. Pall sales of capital equipments for these markets can be large, lumpy and long term. 
Results today can reflect orders that's as long as two years ago, such as the case in Fuels and Chemicals, where sales decreased 11% in the quarter, reflecting reduced capital orders earlier. Good news here is that the base business has grown 5% after four quarters of double-digit declines. This reflects increasing production particularly in Asia and the Middle East.
Orders increased 6% in Q4 on top of 84% growth in Q3. The large increase in the third quarter includes the Tecnimont job we recently announced. The backlog in Fuels and Chemicals currently exceeds $100 million, an increase of more than 24% over last year.
Power Generation was down 13% in the quarter, but a bright spot of late has been the rapid expansion of the wind turbine market in China and Pall's share has been growing dramatically. Looking ahead, Q4 orders in Power Gen picked up over 40% with base orders, including housings, increasing 50%. Systems orders increased 7%. And these orders for housing and systems work has the growing customer confidence in future demand for Energy. Overall, the backlog in Pall Energy exceeds $165 million, which is up 28% over fiscal '09. 
Let's move on to Municipal Water. This market group's 7% in the quarter, driven by a 57% increase in the Western Hemisphere. The Municipal Water market is, for now, a U.S. centric, although the opportunity is decidedly global. The U.S. market remains strong as municipalities continue to upgrade member infiltration -- to member infiltrations to comply with EPA regulations. U.S. orders almost doubled compared to this time last year, and project activity is accelerating in Asia. We entered fiscal 2011 with $100 million backlog in Muni Water, which is more than a 30% over 2009. This is our highest ever in this market.
Aeropower, now comprised of Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment markets represent 17% of total Pall sales in 2010. Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment are roughly the same size, and overall this Aeropower market grew 4% in the quarter, as M&A grew 28% and is now approaching 2008 levels. Mining, steel and automotive production are good examples of markets driving current results. 
Aerospace was down 14% compared to Q4 '09. It did improve sequentially. Commercial Aero was up slightly after four down quarters, and Military Aero was down as expected. Aeropower orders increased almost 60% with both markets, and in Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment, growing above 50%. All submarkets and regions also contributed. And the backlog in Aeropower is up 18% over the fiscal '09 numbers. 
Now finally, let's go to Microelectronics. Microelectronics finished the fourth quarter up over 35% in sales and 20% for the year, outperforming our full year expectations. The market is being driven by near full utilization rates and chip manufacturers and an improving consumer appetite for electronic products. Recovery is in full swing here at all regions and key segments of this diverse market are participating from chip production to the OEMs that supply the industry, consumer electronics, such as flat-panel displays, printers and new opportunities, including the emerging High Bright LED market. Growth in MicroE shows no signs abating based on our current order of book and Q4 orders increased 33%. Now with that, let me have Lisa review the financial details.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011.Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share compared
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011.
Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share compared to $69.5 million or $0.58 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share as defined on Slide 22 were $0.72 compared to $0.57 per share, an increase of 26%. Net earnings for the full year was $241.2 million or $2.03 per share compared to $195.6 million or $1.64 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share were $2.12 compared to $1.77 a year ago, an increase of 20%. Foreign currency translation did not impact earnings per share on the quarter, while an increased earnings per share by $0.10 for the full year.
Sale increased 4% in the quarter. Foreign currency translations decreased the top line by about $12 million or 2%. This was primarily due to the weakening of the euro and to a lesser extent, the British pound against the dollar. The strength of the Japanese yen and several other Asian currencies partly offset this. Excluding this impact, sales were up 6% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2009, reflecting an 8% increase in consumables and a 6% decrease in systems.
Sales increased 3% for the year. Foreign currency translation added about $58 million or 2.5% to our top line. This was primarily the result of the weakening dollar against most Asian currencies, the euro and Canadian dollar. Excluding this impact, sales were up slightly in the year compared to fiscal year 2009. This reflects a 3% increase in consumables, with a 15% decrease in systems.
Pricing gains in Life Sciences and Industrial contributed approximately $5 million in the quarter and approximately $12 million in Life Sciences, partly offset by a decline in Industrial for the full year. Gross margins in the fourth quarter improved 370 basis points to 49.8%, with contributions from both businesses. Pall Industrial's gross margins came in at 47.8%, up 570 basis points year-over-year. Key drivers noted in our third quarter continued into the fourth quarter, volume increases at high-margin markets positively impacting mix and overhead absorption, as well as cost savings outpacing inflationary items.
Life Sciences gross margins also improved the year-over-year, coming in at 51.9%, up 160 basis points. This reflects continued pricing improvement and manufacturing cost reductions. The decline from the third quarter is principally attributable to mix. SG&A was 27.8% of sales in the fourth quarter, down from 30% in the third quarter. Year-over-year, SG&A increased 5%, excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. And for the year, SG&A increased by 3.5%, excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. The majority of this increase relates to investments we're making to drive sales up and SG&A down. These include the costs of the European management center, the implementation of our global ERP systems and investments in selling and marketing costs, principally in emerging regions. The remainder is attributable to inflation being largely offset by cost reductions. 
Turning to income taxes, the effective tax rate, or the as-reported tax rate, for the year was 26.4%. Excluding items that we do not consider to be recurring and therefore did not include in the calculation of pro forma earnings per share, Pall's underlying tax rate for the year was 31% favorable to the 31.3% forecasted for the year.
Net interest expense in the year reflects the benefit of reversing interest accrued of approximately $11 million primarily related to the resolution of certain foreign tax audits. Excluding these items, net interest expense decreased by $2 million.
Turning now to cash flow. Operating cash flow in the year was $378 million compared to $327 million last year, an increase of over $50 million or about 15%. This reflects improvements in working capital management, particularly accounts payable terms, resulting in a reduction of our cash conversion cycle of about 13 days. This was offset by increased taxes paid and pension funding. 
Other significant uses of cash during the year included $136 million in capital spending, reflecting increased investment in our IT infrastructure and wrapping up our headquarters renovation; $100 million to purchase 2.7 million shares of the company's common stock, leaving approximately $350 million on our current authorizations, and this represents the repurchase of $345 million, cumulatively, for the three years ended July 31, 2010, decreasing our shares outstanding by over 10 million, $71 million in dividends to shareholders, the 10% increase year-over-year and $18.5 million for the acquisition of a biotechnology company and certain distribution rights. 
The cash position stood at just under $500 million at July 31, 2010, and our net debt to net debt plus equity was 19.4%, down from 21.4% at July 31, 2009. Indebtedness at July 31, 2010, reflects the previously disclosed public offering of $375 million, 5% senior notes due June 15, 2010, as well as outstandings on our new five-year revolving credit facility of about $250 million. These transactions further secure Pall's liquidity for years to come and enhance our operational flexibility. The timing was optimal given historically low interest rates and the abundance of credit.
We just closed the books on a year of achievement and the second year of Pall's 2013 strategic plan. For those of you who are new to Pall, we updated this plan last December. You can find the plan details on the IR branch of our website. While this plan has many elements, the ultimate measure of success will be in two numbers: Pall's earnings per share; and cash flow generation by the end of fiscal 2013. I'm pleased to report that Pall's results for 2010 in these two critical measures put us on track to meeting our goals under the strategic plan. 
And let's look at the significant drivers. Sales were slightly below with the low-single digit growth in local currency expectation for the year. Sales growth in Life Sciences was on plan, while Industrial sales decline of 3% for the year was below. Obtaining price increases in the Industrial economic environment was challenging. Although we are behind plan there, the Pall Industrial sales organization is very focused on this. As Eric mentioned, crossing the 50% gross margin milestone was significant. This was a 290 basis point step up and was ahead of plan, beneficial mix from the outperforming growth of Pharmaceuticals and BioPharmaceuticals and Microelectronics consumable sales, as well as cost savings in manufacturing, are the highlights for the year.
SG&A at 30.8% of sales is slightly behind plan, reflecting the strategic investments we're making. Life Sciences operating margin of 22.6% is on plan, while Industrial's operating margin of 14.1% is ahead of plan on higher-than-expected gross margins in the back half of the year, mitigating the shortfall. Overall EBIT margin of 16.3% is ahead of plan, and earnings per share of $2.12 were at the high end of our expectations, excluding the headwind of foreign currency translation. We are on track with our cash flow and working capital management objectives.
Looking at 2011, we expect local currency sales growth of mid- to high-single digits in both Life Sciences and Industrial. This is tracking to plan. At current rates, we expect foreign currency translation to be about 1% negative to revenue. 
By market, we expect Medical to improve to low-single digit growth. We expect high-single digit growth in BioPharmaceuticals and for Food and Beverage to grow mid-single digits. In Industrial, we expect the Energy markets to grow at mid-single digits and Water, which will be primarily Systems, to grow double digits for overall growth in Energy & Water of mid single digits. 
We expect the Aerospace to deliver high single to low double-digit growth and Machinery & Equipment to grow by mid single digits. For overall Aeropower, this translates to mid to high single-digit growth. And finally, we expect Microelectronics growth to stabilize at high single-digit growth for the year. 
Gross margins are estimated to be in the range of 50% to 51%, which continues to be ahead of the plan. Pricing, volume and continuing manufacturing efficiencies should be partly offset by mixed headwinds as systems and lower-margin markets are expected to recover. SG&A is forecasted to be about 30.5% of sales, and although this is behind plan, we expect the investments we're making the early years of plan to drive SG&A as well as operational costs down in the out years.
That said, expected EBIT margins of 16% to 17% are on track for the plan. The forecasted underlying income tax rate for 2011 is approximately 27%, which is a 4% reduction in the rate year-over-year as we achieve the August 1 go live for our European headquarters on schedule. 
Pro forma earnings per share is expected to be in a range of $2.35 and $2.55 and includes an approximate $0.03 headwind from foreign currency translation compared to 2010. This is a $0.10 reduction compared to the December 2009 exchange rate used for the plan. Excluding this, earnings per share is tracking to the plan. Operating cash flow is expected to be in a range of $435 million to $460 million, and capital expenditures are expected to increase to $165 million to $175 million as we continue to invest in our IT, infrastructure and manufacturing capabilities.
We have many levers to employ to achieve our earnings per share and cash flow goals for 2013. The bottom line is that Pall's 2010 results have us on track to achieve them, and our expectations for 2011 keep us there. 
Thank you for your attention this morning, and with that, I'll hand this back to Eric.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we look at the Life Sciences side, really, as a whole, I think we expect to see a continuation of the last few years with emerging markets contributing more and more to the Life Sciences pot, if you will. On the Industrial side, we believe that Microel
componenttext: If we look at the Life Sciences side, really, as a whole, I think we expect to see a continuation of the last few years with emerging markets contributing more and more to the Life Sciences pot, if you will. On the Industrial side, we believe that Microelectronics will start to slow again in the second half of our new fiscal year. We're looking at, first, at easy comps but for Aeropower, overall, to recover very nicely this year. Then the whole Energy & Water area, we have basically a good order trend there, not just stability but reinvestment again in new Energy sources, alternative Energy. But geographically, the outlier has been Europe. Europe is particularly weak and especially weak in Industrial for 2010. And there, we do see some good signs of life in Germany, and I think, overall, for the European economies. And this again has been blown out by out August results where orders were quite strong.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010

componenttext: Less nervous, certainly because of the fourth quarter and the orders trend with August in particular, which is generally the weak month in Europe, now coming in fairly strongly.

componenttext: And then in Medical, it sounds like most of the trend, as you alluded to, that we're kind of seeing on those end markets at least you're exposed to are still pretty negative, yet I know you have some of your comps, but it also looks like your new products are gaining some traction. componenttext: The unfavorable underlying trend would be the level of blood collections in the U.S., which has stayed low, dropped a little bit. The other trends are pretty good, particularly in the emerging geographies. So the rapid increase in demand for world-class health care is really taking effect quicker than we would have thought in places like China.

componenttext: Yes, the other driver there is patient protection to reduce hospital-acquired infections, particularly in the U.S. There finally is a realization that, that will save significant amount of the national healthcare spend. headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010

componenttext: Yes, I think what we see in Vaccine is more capacity being added as well as more approvals for vaccines like new vaccines or vaccines that are not new to those countries where they're being approved for use. As far as the other driver, of course, is the move towards single-use disposables in biotechnology for cell growth. And both of those are strong, the larger one, obviously, is the biotech additional capacity. On the Muni market, the Replacement business continued steady. It's a very -- still a relatively low number because on the Municipal Water, our products labs there, I think, last up to eight years. But we are seeing a steady uptick as the volume in place, they're our embedded products from Pall, grows from year-to-year. Look at that eight-year back horizon. And your third question?

componenttext: Well, one good example will be the supply chain, where now, as you know, we have our Chief Operating Officer, Roberto Perez, as responsible for both Industrial and Life Science. componenttext: Well, we do age it to see when we believe that it will shipped, and we also look at it historically in terms of conversion. componenttext: When we look at the backlog at the end of the year, and the growth particularly in orders and backlog for Industrial, that plays very heavily into our first-half projection. headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Pall Corp's. Conference Call and Webcast for the Fourth Quarter and Year End for Fiscal 2010. [Operator Instructions] We would like to remind you that the company's fourth quarter and year-end press release is available at www.pall.com. Managem
componenttext: Welcome to Pall Corp's. Conference Call and Webcast for the Fourth Quarter and Year End for Fiscal 2010. [Operator Instructions] We would like to remind you that the company's fourth quarter and year-end press release is available at www.pall.com. Management's remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements. Please refer to Slide 2 or request a copy of the specific wording of this qualification of the company's remarks. Management also uses certain non-GAAP measures to assess the company's performance. Reconciliations of these measures to their GAAP counterparts are included in the slides at the end of the presentation. At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Eric Krasnoff, Pall Corp's. Chairman and CEO. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Cont
componenttext:
Well, thank you very much. Good morning. We appreciate you joining us today as we report our fiscal 2010 fourth quarter and full year results. Joining me this morning are Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Controller.
Now in addition to reviewing the fourth quarter's performance and recapping the year, we will also be providing guidance for our fiscal year 2011. We look forward to your questions at the end of our prepared remarks. As reported last evening, Pall posted a solid fourth quarter and so an upturn in momentum for the second half of the fiscal year. 
Through a judicious cost management, we position Pall to benefit as business conditions improve and we continue to invest and focus on our growth strategy, new products, market applications and regions. Pall announced the ambitious performance goals for fiscal '10 last December. Lisa will discuss key drivers with some detail a little later. The bottom line, pro forma EPS of $2.12 was within our original guidance of $2.02 to $2.19 and was at the high end, excluding foreign exchange. 
Given better-than-expected performance in the fourth quarter, principally in BioPharmaceuticals, Microelectronics and Machinery & Equipment, EPS exceeded the high end of the guidance we provided after the second quarter. Operating cash flows came in at $378 million compared to our high-end estimate of $365 million. 
Life Sciences performed well all year, particularly in the key BioPharmaceuticals market, which grew over 10% in local currency. Our Industrial business finished the year with sales down 3%. The global recession and consequent drop in industrial manufacturing activity slowly abated as our year progressed. The effect of scant capital spending is still being felt in our Systems business where the order-to-shipment cycle can be as long as two years. At midyear, Microelectronics rebounded and other sectors began to stir. Industrial turned positive again beginning in the third quarter on the strength of a handful of markets and the remaining markets are now also setting up to grow again.
Total orders grew 19% on the fourth quarter, our focusing in on Pall Industrial, their orders grew 26% over last year's Q4, with all Industrial markets contributing. This follows a 54% increase in orders for Industrial in the third quarter. 
Now staying with Industrial, orders for consumables grew 38% following on a 42% increase in Q3. This reflects increase in customer capacity utilization, some inventory restocking and a revival of customer advertisement capital expenditure. 
A positive for the year was the improvement in gross margin that came in at just above 50%. Those of you who have been following us know that we've been chipping away our cost of sales. We were gratified to see this heavy lifting of reducing our manufacturing footprint and instilling a lean culture, improving margins on systems and implementing our pricing excellence program, not just to offset the effects of a weak economy as they did in 2009 but enable us to leverage improving top line in the second half of fiscal '10. 
Before I hand off to Lisa, I'll run down Q4 results by market and give an indication of what we're seeing as we enter our new year. As you saw in the press release last evening, we've made several organizational changes to better manage the business. These changes are illustrated on Slide 6. All year-over-year comparisons are on a restated basis and the discussion on sales and orders with the local currency unless otherwise stated.
Fourth quarter sales came at $679 million and this is up 4% over last year on an as-reported basis. Currency turned from favorable for months of the year to a headwind. Sales grew 6% overall with Life Science, up over 7.5% and Industrial, positive for the second quarter in a row, growing 4%. Sales in the Western Hemisphere increased 14%, with Industrial markets leading at a 20% growth. Europe was down close to 3%, on weakness in several Industrial markets, and Asia overall grew 10%. 
Let's look at the details starting with Life Sciences. BioPharmaceuticals now represent a quarter of Pall's total sales. It's been a steady contributor. In the fourth quarter, we saw a 10% increase in both consumables and system sales and all regions grew. Some of the key drivers: increased production and filtration in terms of biotech drugs, the vaccine remarket is remaining strong market, the market for single-use technologies is expanding and emerging markets are beginning to move the needle. 
In short order, China has become the third largest market for drugs in the world. Consumable sales in Asia grew 10% in the year, even though Japan, Pall's largest Asian country, was flat. Q4 orders increased over 17% and systems orders increased over 100% as capital spending has come back in this market. We entered fiscal year '11 with a strong backlog, up almost 30%.
Turning to Medical. They had a very good closing quarter with sales up 3.6%. The Blood in critical care markets performed. Blood filter sales increased over 3% despite the continuing trend of reduced collections in the U.S. New products here are playing a key role. Hospital critical care had a good quarter with sales up 8%. Sales in Europe were also up about 8%, where the market for water filters is largest and sales in Asia were up sharply. 
New products, as I mentioned before, are key to Medical's growth and about 30% of our sales for the year came from recently introduced products. These higher margin products continue to make Medical a strong contributor to Life Sciences profit growth in the quarter. Q4 orders increased almost 6%.
Looking now at Food and Beverage, which has moved from Industrial and was integrated within the Life Science business. In the quarter, it had also returned to growth. Sales were up over 8% in all regions, with all regions contributing, that is. Consumable sales, a reflection of increasing production increased about 5.5%. System sales nearly doubled in Food and Beverage from the third quarter to the fourth, reflecting improving orders starting in the second quarter. Q4 orders for both consumables and systems increased double digits, and we enter fiscal '11 with a backlog that's up 34% over fiscal '09.
Now I'll switch gears for a review of Pall Industrial, which after a challenging start began to grow in the second half. Much of this growth was driven by the return of Microelectronics. Other markets remain spotty with pockets of market in geographic strength. Orders increased 26% in the quarter and became widespread. And the entry backlog for Industrial is $465 million, an increase of 28%, again over fiscal '09. 
Now looking at the markets, Energy & Water, which was 20% of Pall's sales in 2010, now consists of three submarkets: Fuels and Chemicals, the largest of the three; Power Generation; and Municipal Water. These market share common imperatives for high yields for protecting assets worth hundreds of millions of dollars in each plant and meeting increasingly stringent environmental regs. Pall sales of capital equipments to these markets can be large, lumpy and long term. 
Results today can reflect orders that's as long as two years ago, such as the case in Fuels and Chemicals, where sales decreased 11% in the quarter, reflecting reduced capital orders earlier. Good news here is that the base business has grown 5% after four quarters of double-digit declines. This reflects increasing production particularly in Asia and the Middle East.
Orders increased 6% in Q4 on top of 84% growth in Q3. The large increase in the third quarter includes the Tecnimont job we recently announced. The backlog in Fuels and Chemicals currently exceeds $100 million, an increase of more than 24% over last year.
Power Generation was down 13% in the quarter, but a bright spot of late has been the rapid expansion of the wind turbine market in China and Pall's share has been growing dramatically. Looking ahead, Q4 orders in Power Gen picked up over 40% with base orders, including housings, increasing 50%. Systems orders increased 7%. And these orders for housing and systems work has the growing customer confidence in future demand for Energy. Overall, the backlog in Pall Energy exceeds $165 million, which is up 28% over fiscal '09. 
Let's move on to Municipal Water. This market group's 7% in the quarter, driven by a 57% increase in the Western Hemisphere. The Municipal Water market is, for now, a U.S. centric, although the opportunity is decidedly global. The U.S. market remains strong as municipalities continue to upgrade member infiltration -- to member infiltrations to comply with EPA regulations. U.S. orders almost doubled compared to this time last year, and project activity is accelerating in Asia. We entered fiscal 2011 with $100 million backlog in Muni Water, which is more than a 30% over 2009. This is our highest ever in this market.
Aeropower, now comprised of Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment markets represent 17% of total Pall sales in 2010. Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment are roughly the same size, and overall this Aeropower market grew 4% in the quarter, as M&A grew 28% and is now approaching 2008 levels. Mining, steel and automotive production are good examples of markets driving current results. 
Aerospace was down 14% compared to Q4 '09. It did improve sequentially. Commercial Aero was up slightly after four down quarters, and Military Aero was down as expected. Aeropower orders increased almost 60% with both markets, and in Aerospace and Machinery & Equipment, growing above 50%. All submarkets and regions also contributed. And the backlog in Aeropower is up 18% over the fiscal '09 numbers. 
Now finally, let's go to Microelectronics. Microelectronics finished the fourth quarter up over 35% in sales and 20% for the year, outperforming our full year expectations. The market is being driven by near full utilization rates and chip manufacturers and an improving consumer appetite for electronic products. Recovery is in full swing here at all regions and key segments of this diverse market are participating from chip production to the OEMs that supply the industry, consumer electronics, such as flat-panel displays, printers and new opportunities, including the emerging High Bright LED market. Growth in MicroE shows no signs abating based on our current order of book and Q4 orders increased 33%. Now with that, let me have Lisa review the financial details.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011.Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share compared
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter and the year and end with our current expectations for fiscal year 2011.
Net earnings in the quarter were $55 million or $0.46 per share compared to $69.5 million or $0.58 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share as defined on Slide 22 were $0.72 compared to $0.57 per share, an increase of 26%. Net earnings for the full year was $241.2 million or $2.03 per share compared to $195.6 million or $1.64 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share were $2.12 compared to $1.77 a year ago, an increase of 20%. Foreign currency translation did not impact earnings per share on the quarter, while an increased earnings per share by $0.10 for the full year.
Sale increased 4% in the quarter. Foreign currency translations decreased the top line by about $12 million or 2%. This was primarily due to the weakening of the euro and to a lesser extent, the British pound against the dollar. The strength of the Japanese yen and several other Asian currencies partly offset this. Excluding this impact, sales were up 6% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal year 2009, reflecting an 8% increase in consumables and a 6% decrease in systems.
Sales increased 3% for the year. Foreign currency translation added about $58 million or 2.5% to our top line. This was primarily the result of the weakening dollar against most Asian currencies, the euro and Canadian dollar. Excluding this impact, sales were up slightly in the year compared to fiscal year 2009. This reflects a 3% increase in consumables, with a 15% decrease in systems.
Pricing gains in Life Sciences and Industrial contributed approximately $5 million in the quarter and approximately $12 million in Life Sciences, partly offset by a decline in Industrial for the full year. Gross margins in the fourth quarter improved 370 basis points to 49.8%, with contributions from both businesses. Pall Industrial's gross margins came in at 47.8%, up 570 basis points year-over-year. Key drivers noted in our third quarter continued into the fourth quarter, volume increases at high-margin markets positively impacting mix and overhead absorption, as well as cost savings outpacing inflationary items.
Life Sciences gross margins also improved the year-over-year, coming in at 51.9%, up 160 basis points. This reflects continued pricing improvement and manufacturing cost reductions. The decline from the third quarter is principally attributable to mix. SG&A was 27.8% of sales in the fourth quarter, down from 30% in the third quarter. Year-over-year, SG&A increased 5%, excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. And for the year, SG&A increased by 3.5%, excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. The majority of this increase relates to investments we're making to drive sales up and SG&A down. These include the costs of the European management center, the implementation of our global ERP systems and investments in selling and marketing costs, principally in emerging regions. The remainder is attributable to inflation being largely offset by cost reductions. 
Turning to income taxes. The effective tax rate, or the as-reported tax rate for the year was 26.4%. Excluding items that we do not consider to be recurring and therefore did not include in the calculation of pro forma earnings per share, Pall's underlying tax rate for the year was 31% favorable to the 31.3% forecasted for the year. Net interest expense in the year reflects the benefit of reversing interest accrued of approximately $11 million primarily related to the resolution of certain foreign tax audits. Excluding these items, net interest expense decreased by $2 million.
Turning now to cash flow. Operating cash flow in the year was $378 million compared to $327 million last year, an increase of over $50 million or about 15%. This reflects improvements in working capital management, particularly accounts payable terms, resulting in a reduction of our cash conversion cycle of about 13 days. This was offset by increased taxes paid and pension funding. 
Other significant uses of cash during the year included $136 million in capital spending, reflecting increased investment in our IT infrastructure and wrapping up our headquarters renovation; $100 million to purchase 2.7 million shares of the company's common stock, leaving approximately $350 million on our current authorizations, and this represents the repurchase of $345 million, cumulatively, for the three years ended July 31, 2010, decreasing our shares outstanding by over 10 million, $71 million in dividends to shareholders, the 10% increase year-over-year and $18.5 million for the acquisition of a biotechnology company and certain distribution rights. 
The cash position stood at just under $500 million at July 31, 2010, and our net debt to net debt plus equity was 19.4%, down from 21.4% at July 31, 2009. Indebtedness at July 31, 2010, reflects the previously disclosed public offering of $375 million, 5% senior notes due June 15, 2010, as well as outstandings on our new five-year revolving credit facility of about $250 million. These transactions further secure Pall's liquidity for years to come and enhance our operational flexibility. The timing was optimal given historically low interest rates and the abundance of credit.
We just closed the books on a year of achievement and the second year of Pall's 2013 strategic plan. For those of you who are new to Pall, we updated this plan last December. You can find the plan details on the IR branch of our website. While this plan has many elements, the ultimate measure of success will be in two numbers: Pall's earnings per share and cash flow generation by the end of fiscal 2013. I'm pleased to report that Pall's results for 2010 in these two critical measures put us on track to meeting our goals under the strategic plan. 
And let's look at the significant drivers. Sales were slightly below with a low-single digit growth in local currency expectation for the year. Sales growth in Life Sciences was on plan, while Industrial sales decline of 3% for the year was below. Obtaining price increases in the Industrial economic environment was challenging. Although we are behind plan there, the Pall Industrial sales organization is very focused on this. As Eric mentioned, crossing the 50% gross margin milestone was significant. This was a 290 basis point step up and was ahead of plan. Beneficial mix from the outperforming growth of Pharmaceuticals and BioPharmaceuticals and Microelectronics consumable sales, as well as cost savings in manufacturing, are the highlights for the year.
SG&A at 30.8% of sales is slightly behind plan, reflecting the strategic investments we're making. Life Sciences operating margin of 22.6% is on plan, while Industrial's operating margin of 14.1% is ahead of plan on higher-than-expected gross margins in the back half of the year, mitigating the shortfall. Overall EBIT margin of 16.3% is ahead of plan, and earnings per share of $2.12 were at the high end of our expectations, excluding the headwind of foreign currency translation. We are on track with our cash flow and working capital management objectives.
Looking at 2011, we expect local currency sales growth of mid- to high-single digits in both Life Sciences and Industrial. This is tracking to plan. At current rates, we expect foreign currency translation to be about 1% negative to revenue. 
By market, we expect Medical to improve to low-single digit growth. We expect high-single digit growth in BioPharmaceuticals and for Food and Beverage to grow mid-single digits. In Industrial, we expect the Energy markets to grow at mid-single digits and Water, which will be primarily Systems, to grow double digits for overall growth in Energy & Water of mid single digits. 
We expect the Aerospace to deliver high single to low double-digit growth and Machinery & Equipment to grow by mid single digits. For overall Aeropower, this translates to mid to high single-digit growth. And finally, we expect Microelectronics growth to stabilize at high single-digit growth for the year. 
Gross margins are estimated to be in the range of 50% to 51%, which continues to be ahead of the plan. Pricing, volume and continuing manufacturing efficiencies should be partly offset by mixed headwinds as systems and lower-margin markets are expected to recover. SG&A is forecasted to be about 30.5% of sales, and although this is behind plan, we expect the investments we're making in the early years of the plan to drive SG&A as well as operational costs down in the out years.
That said, expected EBIT margins of 16% to 17% are on track for the plan. The forecasted underlying income tax rate for 2011 is approximately 27%, which is a 4% reduction in the rate year-over-year as we achieve the August 1 go live for our European headquarters on schedule. 
Pro forma earnings per share is expected to be in a range of $2.35 and $2.55 and includes an approximate $0.03 headwind from foreign currency translation compared to 2010. This is a $0.10 reduction compared to the December 2009 exchange rate used for the plan. Excluding this, earnings per share is tracking to the plan. Operating cash flow is expected to be in the range of $435 million to $460 million, and capital expenditures are expected to increase to $165 million to $175 million as we continue to invest in our IT, infrastructure and manufacturing capabilities.
We have many levers to employ to achieve our earnings per share and cash flow goals for 2013. The bottom line is that Pall's 2010 results have us on track to achieve them, and our expectations for 2011 keep us there. 
Thank you for your attention this morning, and with that, I'll hand this back to Eric.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: If we look at the Life Sciences side, really, as a whole, I think we expect to see a continuation of the last few years, with emerging markets contributing more and more to the Life Sciences pot, if you will. On the Industrial side, we believe that Microe
componenttext: If we look at the Life Sciences side, really, as a whole, I think we expect to see a continuation of the last few years, with emerging markets contributing more and more to the Life Sciences pot, if you will. On the Industrial side, we believe that Microelectronics will start to slow again in the second half of our new fiscal year. We're looking at, first, at easy comps but for Aeropower, overall, to recover very nicely this year. Then the whole Energy & Water area, we'd see basically a good order trend there, not just stability but reinvestment again in new Energy sources, alternative Energy. But geographically, the outlier has been Europe. Europe is particularly weak and especially weak in Industrial for 2010. And there, we do see some good signs of life in Germany, and I think, overall, for the European economies. And this again has been borne out by our August results where orders were quite strong.

componenttext: And then in Medical, it sounds like most of the trend, as you alluded to, that we're kind of seeing on those end markets at least you're exposed to are still pretty negative, yet I know you have some of your comps, but it also looks like your new products are gaining some traction. componenttext: The unfavorable underlying trend would be the level of blood collections in the U.S., which has stayed low, dropped a little bit. The other trends are pretty good, particularly in the emerging geographies. componenttext: Overall, we're not seeing a lot of activity in the Muni Water side in Europe, but we're seeing it very strong in the U.S., which is the much larger segment for Municipal Water. headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping to get a little bit more clarity on the Life Sciences market in terms of what's driving more of the growth between vaccine and drugs. Do you see more plants coming on in the Vaccine segment or the Drug segment? And then secondly, if you could
componenttext: I was hoping to get a little bit more clarity on the Life Sciences market in terms of what's driving more of the growth between vaccine and drugs. Do you see more plants coming on in the Vaccine segment or the Drug segment? And then secondly, if you could comment on the replacement market for the Muni business? And then lastly, a couple of quick specifics on your Lean initiatives for 2011.

headline: Pall Corp., Q4 2010 Earnings Call, Sep 15, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think what we see in Vaccine is more capacity being added as well as more approvals for vaccines like new vaccines or vaccines that are not new to those countries where they're being approved for use. As far as the other driver, of course, is the m
componenttext: Yes, I think what we see in Vaccine is more capacity being added as well as more approvals for vaccines like new vaccines or vaccines that are not new to those countries where they're being approved for use. As far as the other driver, of course, is the move towards single-use disposables in biotechnology for cell growth. And both of those are strong, the larger one, obviously, is the biotech additional capacity. On the Muni market, the Replacement business continued steady. It's a very -- still a relatively low number because on the Municipal Water, our products labs there, I think, last up to eight years. But we are seeing a steady uptick as the volume in place, they're our embedded products from Pall, grows from year-to-year. Look at that eight-year back horizon. And your third question?

For Life Sciences, our backlog tends to not be as meaningful because orders ship pretty quickly.

componenttext: The 27% is the underlying rate for the full year. So absent any unusual or discrete items through the course of the year, 27% should be the rate that you should expect to see in all of the quarters. I would say that similar to what we saw in the fourth quarter of this year where we had some incremental tax cost as a result of the conversion to the European headquarters, as we progressed through 2011 and we continue to convert Pall Industrial, as well as our Asian headquarters, we may see in 2011 some incremental tax costs there. That's not included in this 27% underlying rate because it's not yet estimable.
