componenttext: I want to follow up on sort of what you were alluding to at the end, and maybe giving us a little more insight on -- you started off with such a strong first quarter. The dynamics you see in the second, should we be expecting sort of normalized seasonal sequential progressions? Or is there very specific guidance that may be a delta from typical?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we've given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year, that our expectations on earnings growth are 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter. Looking at the seco
componenttext: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we've given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year, that our expectations on earnings growth are 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter. Looking at the second quarter, there are some areas where we may not see growth quite a strong as in the first quarter in areas such as Aeropower and a couple of the other Industrial areas. So typically, we, our revenues increased sequentially throughout the year, and that may not be the case Q2 to Q1.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Eric, as a follow-up on that, you mentioned some specific -- in MicroE you have a short view, a shorter-term view. We're obviously in the volatile season for that with the holidays and New Year's and post-Christmas changeovers and the like. Any insigh
componenttext: And Eric, as a follow-up on that, you mentioned some specific -- in MicroE you have a short view, a shorter-term view. We're obviously in the volatile season for that with the holidays and New Year's and post-Christmas changeovers and the like. Any insight at least as to your expectation or what the customer base is -- could you give me a feedback on at the moment?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor chip IC driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductors side, what we'
componenttext: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor chip IC driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductors side, what we're hearing is that there's going to be a retrenchment and capital spend, but not in the basic rate of chip production, which would mean for us a slowing or flattening perhaps of growth in the second half of the year, but also an improvement in the product mix as, if the consumables side stays stronger.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Dane in for Jon. Just a quick question on the system sales. From the commentary, there is the expectation that there is just going to be a surge in the back half of this fiscal year. Maybe if you could just kind of parse out some details
componenttext: This is actually Dane in for Jon. Just a quick question on the system sales. From the commentary, there is the expectation that there is just going to be a surge in the back half of this fiscal year. Maybe if you could just kind of parse out some details and kind of like, based on current forecast, what kind of percentage of sales that could get up to? Are we thinking that maybe that could get back to like a teens' percentage of total revenue sales? Then kind of maybe just give a little color around, are these orders already in the backlog, or is there an anticipation of orders coming through in the next couple of quarters here that may be realized around the fourth quarter timeframe?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third a
componenttext: So looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third and fourth quarter, up to say, 18% to 20% of sales in say, the fourth quarter. In terms of backlog, a substantial or say, lion's share of what we're forecasting for systems revenue for the year is pretty much in the backlog. There is some that we're still expecting. And we expect that, that should happen by the end of this month into the end of January.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And kind of what sub-segments is the majority -- I know in the past you mentioned kind of Muni Water is being some of these larger systems sales. Any other segments that we should be thinking about?
componenttext: And kind of what sub-segments is the majority -- I know in the past you mentioned kind of Muni Water is being some of these larger systems sales. Any other segments that we should be thinking about?

componenttext: The sectors in addition to Muni Water that you would be thinking about are clearly Energy and Aeropower, and Food and Beverage.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Chris Parkinson on behalf of Hamzah. Could you just talk a little more about how pricing is currently trending and how aggressive you believe you're being relative to your competitors in the marketplace, please?
componenttext: This is Chris Parkinson on behalf of Hamzah. Could you just talk a little more about how pricing is currently trending and how aggressive you believe you're being relative to your competitors in the marketplace, please?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we can't comment on our competitors' pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side. And that's been the trend for the last couple of yea
componenttext: Actually, we can't comment on our competitors' pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side. And that's been the trend for the last couple of years I think because of the macroeconomics. We expect that the economy now is recovering and has much more robust demand on Industrial, we'll be seeing better price increasing as we go into the last three quarters of this year. We're targeting 1%, basically, maybe a bit over that, as a reasonable expectation for the year. Pall is, in many of our markets, we have one or two major competitors and we are very disciplined, and believe that we are a leader in price.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up, could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business? And basically, what type of incremental margins are you currently seeing and how much further our cost takeup has been left on the horizon?
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up, could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business? And basically, what type of incremental margins are you currently seeing and how much further our cost takeup has been left on the horizon?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the current, at the operating margin level, we're see incremental margins of 40% to 50%, in general. And clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix, very strong consumables quarter, and markets like Pharma and Microelectronics and
componenttext: Well, the current, at the operating margin level, we're see incremental margins of 40% to 50%, in general. And clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix, very strong consumables quarter, and markets like Pharma and Microelectronics and M&E driving a very, very strong incremental margin. As we progress throughout the year, we would expect to start to see that certainly come down as systems sales and lower-margin markets make up a higher preponderance of our book of business.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Wood with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Wood with Jefferies.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

componenttext: Lisa, just to follow up on that last question, the last update, I think, you guys provided was 25% to 30% contribution margin on the systems. Has that changed at all over the last couple of quarters?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It actually changed a bit in the first quarter. And by the way, that was gross margin as opposed to contribution margin. In our first quarter, we did have some pretty good margin, gross margins on systems' unique quarter relative to some water trailers. S
componenttext: It actually changed a bit in the first quarter. And by the way, that was gross margin as opposed to contribution margin. In our first quarter, we did have some pretty good margin, gross margins on systems' unique quarter relative to some water trailers. So that did add a bit to gross margin in this quarter in addition to the fact that systems sales were light in the quarter. We don't necessarily expect to see that continuing. We expect that we would be back into the 25% to 30% gross margin range for the book of systems in the back part of the year.

componenttext: Yes, we've revamped the R&D structure. We have a Chief Technology Officer now. I think we put out a press release. componenttext: We would expect that Life Sciences margins may -- operating margins may dip a little bit as couple of things happen. Also in Life Sciences, between Food and Beverage and BioPharma, we do expect to see a ramp-up of systems. And I will add that Life Sciences' gross margins and operating margins have seen a little bit of pressure from the weakening of the euro against -- the euro for us against two key currencies, the pound and the dollar, so against last year and going into the year, so we saw a little bit of pressure in this quarter year-over-year and depending upon what the euro does, that may put some pressure as well.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, just one other question for Lisa, going back to your five-year plan and the recent goals that you put out, I think that you're long-term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25%-ish range. And can you update us on couple of your initiativ
componenttext: And then, just one other question for Lisa, going back to your five-year plan and the recent goals that you put out, I think that you're long-term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25%-ish range. And can you update us on couple of your initiatives over the next couple of years that are going to get you there and whether those are on track and if we can still expect that type of tax rate eventually?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the first initiative, which is what got us from 31-ish% to 27-ish% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we're working on this year that would go -- that we would se
componenttext: Sure. Well, the first initiative, which is what got us from 31-ish% to 27-ish% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we're working on this year that would go -- that we would see come to fruition in the financial results in fiscal year 2012 is doing something similar with our Industrial leadership for Europe, centralizing that into Switzerland. And then, the last key leg of that tax forecast is Asia. And we are centralizing our Asian leadership into Singapore. And so, both Switzerland and Singapore are both places that we've negotiated favorable tax position. And in both places, we're putting our leadership managing our supply chain, demand planning. And we're on track with all those things, so working quite diligently through fiscal year '11 to see it come into effect in 2012.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Pall Corporation's conference call and webcast for the first quarter for fiscal 2011. Today's call is being recorded and simultaneously webcast and instructions for the question-and-answer session will be provided at the end of management's pre
componenttext:
Welcome to Pall Corporation's conference call and webcast for the first quarter for fiscal 2011. Today's call is being recorded and simultaneously webcast and instructions for the question-and-answer session will be provided at the end of management's prepared remarks. Right now, all lines are in a listen-only mode.
We would like to remind you that the company's first quarter press release is available at www.pall.com.
Management's remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements. Please refer to slide two or request a copy of the specific wording of this qualification of the company's remarks. Management also uses certain non-GAAP measures to assess the company's performance. Reconciliations of these measures to their GAAP counterparts are included in the slides at the end of the presentation.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Eric Krasnoff, Pall Corporation's Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here to review Pall's first quarter results with you. Thanks for joining us. I am here this morning with Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer and Frank Moschella, Corporate Controller. Lisa and I will review some
componenttext:
Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here to review Pall's first quarter results with you. Thanks for joining us. I am here this morning with Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer and Frank Moschella, Corporate Controller. Lisa and I will review some of the details and drivers of the quarter and following that we look forward to your questions.
The first quarter provided a good start to the year. Sales were $605 million, a 12% increase in local currency. Negative exchange rates reduced this by 1.5%. Revenues increased by double digits in both businesses with sales growth broad-based by market and geography. Overall orders increased 7% with consumables growing just over 8% and the backlog is up over 20% in both consumables and systems.
Life Sciences continued to perform well. The top line grew over 10% and margins improved. The lead story this quarter was the reemergence of Industrial, sales grew 14% with healthy contributions from just about every sector. Industrial's gross margins jumped 300 basis points to 47.2%. Operating profit almost doubled from a year ago. On a geographic basis, sales grew in both Industrial and Life Sciences in all regions.
The Western Hemisphere grew over 25% led by Industrial, where sales increased 39%. Europe and Asia grew 5% and 8% respectively. The emerging regions we have been focusing on including Latin America, MENA, China, India and Southeast Asia, which represent about 20% of total sales, grew over 20% as well. The strong top line coupled with Pall’s steeply growing [ph] productivity improvement culture drove gross margins up to 51% and operating margins over 17%, which was a significant achievement.
With that, let’s look at the details starting with Life Sciences. BioPharmaceuticals, which represents about 25% of Pall’s total sales, had another strong quarter. Revenues increased about 15% with pharmaceuticals and laboratory growing at similar rates. Consumable sales were up almost 14% and system sales increased 30%. The biotech and plasma markets remained strong while the vaccine market was flat even without a separate vaccine for H1N1 this year.
Demand for Pall’s single-use technologies also continues to drive growth. All regions advanced with the Western Hemisphere and Asia particularly robust at about 25% growth each. Sales in Europe grew 5%. Sales in the emerging regions while small are growing quickly driven by increasing demand and higher local standards from medical care.
Orders remained strong in BioPharmaceuticals with booking for Pharma consumables up over 25%. Medical also had a good quarter with sales up 5% and all regions contributing. Blood Filtration sales grew slightly despite modest reductions in blood collections in the Western Hemisphere.
The OEM sub-market grew 19%. This reflects increased medical device production and new business for our proprietary materials. The hospital critical care market also grew slightly. Self therapy, a small revenue base today but exciting for the future continued to grow by double digits.
Sales in Food & Beverage grew almost 9%. Let's note, however, the comparison of Q1 is to the lowest point in fiscal 2010 where Food & Beverage sales dropped 18%. All regions have now returned to positive territory led by the Western Hemisphere at 25% and Asia at 14%.
Europe, the largest part of the food and beverage market for Pall grew at 4% as the region continues to recover. Consumable sales grew over 11% reflecting increased production and the success of Pall Systems strategy.
There are now about 800 Pall Systems for (inaudible) diafiltration and wine clarification in the field and we're currently working on the biggest pipeline of Systems projects in several years.
Pending legislation currently awaiting House approval could provide an additional boost to Pall's Food & Beverage business over time. The U.S. Senate recently approved the biggest overhaul to the nation's food safety laws since the 1930s. The bill places greater responsibility on manufacturers and farmers to prevent contamination during production. The bill also gives vast new powers to the FDA, which recognize that developed filtration and protecting or preventing contamination and the benefit of process monitoring to ensure quality before final QC.
Now, let's move on to Industrial, which had quite a good quarter. Sales overall increased 14%. Aeropower came back strong at 24% growth, and two of the three Energy and Water submarkets grew double digits. We still saw a weakness in capital spending in the larger fields in chemical submarket. Microelectronics grew over 29%.
So let's look at the details starting with Aeropower, which grew 24% in Q1. Machinery and Equipment posted double-digit growth for the third quarter in a row; this time increasing 32%. Sales almost doubled in the Western Hemisphere, increased about 15% in Europe and almost 19% in Asia. The global mining and primary metals markets are in high gear. Q1 orders were also strong.
Aerospace grew over 15% after four quarters of double-digit declines, both submarkets and all regions contributed. Military Aerospace, up 6%, was driven by Western Hemisphere demand, which was up 10%. Shipments were for multiple military programs, including the Joint Strike Fighter as well as spares for U.S. government. Despite the lack of CH-47 orders, which we had expected, we are maintaining our full-year outlook for aerospace as other opportunities fill in the gaps. Commercial aerospace made a nice comeback in the quarter with 27% growth on contributions from all regions. This reflects some inventory restocking by Pall distributors to the airlines as well as a modest increase in aircraft build rates.
With Energy and Water, Municipal Water and Power Generation performing well within the quarter, we saw 11% growth each. Fuels and Chemicals was down 13%, reflecting the hangover effect of scant capital orders during the economic downturn. This was exacerbated by challenging comps from some very large systems orders that shipped a year ago. Importantly, increased activity in the sector stayed true with consumable sales increasing by over 10%. This is the second quarter in a row of consumables growth after four quarters of double-digit declines. This was driven by the Western Hemisphere at 35% growth and Europe at 17% and reflects increased production of oil, gas, chemicals, and polymers.
Power Generation saw a strong growth in the Western Hemisphere and Asia. Key drivers there were water treatment systems for U.S. power generation stations and continued expansion of the wind turbine market in China. Europe remained weak due to ongoing challenges in the turbomachinery market and from reduced demand for power tied to industrial production.
Municipal Water sales grew 11% in the quarter with sales in the Western Hemisphere up 25%. The U.S. market remained strong as municipalities continue to upgrade to membrane filtration to comply with EPA Water Quality Standards. Europe has been weak, but orders through the last two quarters increased double-digits. The backlog is up to 115 million in municipal water, which is a 25% increase over last year. So overall, we have a mixed bag in Energy and Water booked by market and region. The Energy and Water markets were not hit as hard as many of the other industrial markets, nor are they bouncing back as quickly.
Finally, to save the best for last, Microelectronics; Microelectronics remained strong in the opening quarter with sales up over 29%. All regions and key customer markets grew. Growth continues to reflect high utilization rates of chip producers and healthy consumer demand for advanced Microelectronics, such as LED display technology. We do not expect this rate of growth to continue as production catches up with underlying demand and the comps get tougher. The flat panel display market mix were down due to well-publicized oversupply, but that was not our Q1 experience. Orders, which have been up sharply for four quarters, this time increased 22%. In any case we continue to expect a good year for Microelectronics.
Now with that, Lisa McDermott will review the financial details. Lisa?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter. Net earnings in the quarter were $71.4 million or $0.61 per share compared to $57 million or $0.56 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per sh
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter. Net earnings in the quarter were $71.4 million or $0.61 per share compared to $57 million or $0.56 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per share, as defined on slide 18, was $0.62 compared to $0.40 per share, an increase of 55%.
Foreign currency translation had no material impact on earnings per share in the quarter. Quarter one sales increased by 10.7%, foreign currency translation decreased the top line by about $8 million or 1.4%. This was primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the euro, British pound, and Korean won, partly offset by the weakening of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen and Australian dollar.
Excluding this impact, sales were up 12.1% compared to the first quarter of fiscal year '10 reflecting a 13.6% increase in consumable sales with contributions from both Life Sciences and Industrial. System sales were essentially flat as double-digit growth in Life Sciences was offset by a mid-single digit decline in Industrial.
Pricing gains in Life Sciences and Industrial contributed approximately $3.2 million to the top line. For the full year, we expect local currency sales growth of mid-to-high single digits in both Life Sciences and Industrial. The outlook for some markets has improved a bit since the beginning of the fiscal year.
It now looks like Medical could growth low-to-mid single digits for the year. Biopharmaceuticals is off to a strong start and our original high-single digit outlook now looks like it could be slightly conservative. Our outlook for food and beverage is still for mid-single digit growth.
Aeropower may also have a better year than we originally expected. We now believe Aeropower can deliver a high-single to low-double digit sales growth with Machinery and Equipment growing by high-single to low-double digits and Aerospace growing by low-double digits. Our outlook for Energy and Water is unchanged. We continue to expect the energy markets to grow at mid single-digits, and water, which will be primarily systems, to grow double-digits, for overall growth in the energy and water markets of mid single-digits.
Finally, we continue to expect Microelectronics growth to stabilize at high single-digit for the year. This contemplates maintaining sales at levels similar to this quarter throughout the fiscal year.
Gross margin in the first quarter improved 160 basis points compared to last year, to 51%, with contributions from both businesses. Sequentially, gross margins improved by 120 basis points, and this principally reflects the changing mix from the fourth quarter of 2010 when systems comprised 15% of sales versus about 9% in the first quarter.
Pall Industrial's gross margins came in at 47.2%, up 300 basis points compared to last year, as Eric mentioned. The improvement in margins was primarily due to continued improvement in factory utilization and overhead absorption driven by volume growth. Also, the estimated benefit of cost saving initiatives, including improved efficiency in manufacturing operations, outpaced inflation.
Life Sciences' gross margins also increased, coming in at 54.5%, up 40 basis points. This reflects continued pricing improvement and the benefit of sales channel changes as well as manufacturing cost reductions on a net basis.
We continue to project gross margins for the full year to be in the range of 50% to 51%. Pricing, volume, and continued manufacturing efficiencies should be partly offset by mix headwinds as system sales surge in the later part of the year and lower-margin markets continued to recover.
SG&A was 30.1% of sales in the first quarter, down from 32.3% in the comparable quarter. SG&A expense increased 4.7% excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. Approximately 60% of this increase relates to investments drive sales up and SG&A down in the future. These include the cost of building up our European and Asian headquarters, the implementation of our Global ERP system and investments in emerging regions such as MENA where we opened our new office in Dubai in this past quarter.
The remainder is attributable to inflationary items. Our improved revenue outlook combined with some spending deferred into later in the year which reduces the fiscal year's spend should result in full year SG&A as a percentage of sales at or below 30%.
R&D spending rose about 17% and we expect it will be just under 3.5% of sales for the year. Turning to income taxes, the effective tax rate or as reported rate for the quarter was 26.8% as compared to 10.5% in the first quarter of fiscal year 2010.
Excluding the benefit from the favorable resolution of foreign tax audits during the first quarter of last year, this represents a sustainable reduction year-over-year in the tax rate of about 4% as forecasted. The reduction has contributed about $4 million for the bottom line so far.
The full year forecasted rate of about 27% reflects the tax benefits associated with the establishment of our European headquarters. Net interest expense in the first quarter of last year reflects the benefit of reversing accrued interest of approximately $9 million primarily related to the resolution of the foreign tax audit. Excluding this item, net interest expense increased by approximately $1 million driven by an increase in debt levels compared to the same period of last year.
Earlier this week, we issued $205 million of commercial paper, at just about 1.2% including support cost. This is about 1% lower than the borrowings under our revolver which are being repaid with proceeds from the commercial paper issuance.
Turning now to cash flow. Operating cash flow on the quarter was $58.7 million, compared to $73 million last year, a decrease of $14.5 million or about 20%. This reflects an increase in certain payments tied to fiscal 2010 earnings performance, which was considerably stronger than 2009 such as income taxes and variable base compensation. This was partially offset by continued improvement in working capital management.
Significant uses of cash during the quarter included $62 million return to shareholders, with dividends of $37 million and $25 million to repurchase approximately 580,000 shares of the company's common stock. This leaves approximately $328 million of our current authorization. $25 million in capital spending and $17 million in repayments of debt net of new borrowings.
Our cash position stood at $479 million at October 31st, and our net debt to net debt plus equity was 18.7%, down from 19.4% at the end of fiscal year 2010.
For the full year, we expect operating cash flow to be in the range of $435 million to $460 million, and capital expenditures to be in the range of $165 million to $175 million.
Now, as Eric said this quarter provided a good start to the year. We see the successful execution of key initiatives clearly show improvement in our results from the top to the bottom line. Based upon the first quarter results and outlook, we now expect projected pro forma EPS to be in the range of $2.48 to $2.63 for fiscal 2011.
This reflects the neutral impact from foreign currency translation compared to last year to earnings per share based upon where current rate stands, including a euro-U.S. exchange rate of 1.3 through the last nine months.
Thank you for your attention this morning. With that, I will hand this back to Eric.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much Lisa. Our increased EPS guidance is grounded by what we have seen for the first four months of the year and the market outlook that Lisa shared with us this morning.You should note that our updated outlook provides some caution that
componenttext:
Thank you very much Lisa. Our increased EPS guidance is grounded by what we have seen for the first four months of the year and the market outlook that Lisa shared with us this morning.
You should note that our updated outlook provides some caution that the year-over-year EPS growth is expected to lessen as we move through fiscal 2011. The first quarter included inventory replenishments. One major variable in our guidance is Microelectronics. Our forward visibility in this highly cyclical market is only about three months. We are currently projecting Microelectronics revenues to show no growth in the second half of the year, we’ll see.
Now, we’ve covered a lot ground this morning and appreciate your patience. Now, with the help of the conference operator we are ready for your questions.

componenttext: I want to follow-up on sort of what you were alluding to at the end and maybe give us a little more insight on, you started off with such a strong first quarter. The dynamics you see in the second, should we be expecting sort of normalized seasonal sequential progressions or is there, very specific items that maybe a delta from typical?

componenttextpreview: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we have given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year that our expectations on earnings growth of 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter, looking at the seco
componenttext: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we have given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year that our expectations on earnings growth of 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter, looking at the second quarter, there are some areas where we may not see growth quite as strong as in the first quarter, an area such as Aero Power and a couple of the other industrial areas. So, typically our revenues increased sequentially throughout the year and that may not be the case Q2 through Q1.

componenttext: Eric, as a follow-up on that, you mentioned some specific and Michael, you have a short view, a shorter-term view. We're obviously in the volatile season for that with the holidays and New Year and post-Christmas changeovers and the like. Any insight at least as to your expectation or what the customer base is given your feedback on at the moment?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor, chip, IT driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductor side, what we
componenttext: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor, chip, IT driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductor side, what we're hearing is that there's going to be a retrenchment in capital spend but not in the basic rate of chip production which would mean for us a slowing or flattening perhaps of growth in the second half of the year but also an improvement in product mix as the consumable side stay stronger.

componenttext: This is actually Dane [ph] in for Jon. Just a quick question on the Systems sales. From the commentary there is expectation that there is going to be a surge in the back half of this fiscal year. Maybe you could just kind of parse out some details on kind of like based on current forecast, what kind of percentage of sales that could get up to? Are we thinking that maybe that could get back to like a teens percentage of total revenue sales? Then maybe just give a little color around, are these orders already in the backlog or is there an anticipation of orders coming through in the next couple of quarters here that maybe realized around the fourth quarter timeframe? Thanks.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our Systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to, say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third and
componenttext: Looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our Systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to, say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third and fourth quarter up to, say, 18% to 20% of sales, in say the fourth quarter. In terms of backlog, a substantial or a lion’s share of what we're forecasting for Systems revenue for the year is pretty much in the backlog. There is some that we're still expecting and we expect that that should happen by the end of this month and through the end of January.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure we can comment on our competitor's pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases, and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side, and that's been the trend for the last couple of y
componenttext: I'm not sure we can comment on our competitor's pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases, and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side, and that's been the trend for the last couple of years I think because of the macroeconomics. We expect as the economy now is recovering and as much more robust demand on Industrial, we would be seeing better price increasing as we go into the last three quarters of this year. We're targeting 1% basically, maybe a bit over that as a reasonable expectation for the year. Pall is - in many of our markets we have one or two major competitors and we are very disciplined and believe that we are a leader in price.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a quick follow-up. Could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business and basically what type of incremental margins you're currently seeing, how much further cost takeout has been left on the horizon?
componenttext: Just a quick follow-up. Could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business and basically what type of incremental margins you're currently seeing, how much further cost takeout has been left on the horizon?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the current - at the operating margin level, we're seeing incremental margins of 40% to 50% in general. Clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix; very strong consumables quarter and markets like pharma and microelectronics and M
componenttext: Well, the current - at the operating margin level, we're seeing incremental margins of 40% to 50% in general. Clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix; very strong consumables quarter and markets like pharma and microelectronics and M&E driving a very, very strong incremental margin. As we progress throughout the year, we would expect to start to see that certainly come down as system sales and lower margin markets make up a higher preponderance of our book of business.

componenttext: It actually changed a bit in the first quarter. By the way, that was gross margin as opposed to contribution margin. In our first quarter, we did have some pretty good gross margins on systems, unique quarter relative to some water trailers, so that did add a bit to gross margin in this quarter in addition to the fact that system sales were light in the quarter. We don’t necessarily expect to see that continuing. We expect that we would be back into the 25% to 30% gross margin range for the book of systems in the back part of the year.

componenttext: Yes, we’ve revamped the R&D structure. We have the Chief Technology Officer now. I think we’ve put out a press release. With that we are focusing again on diagnostics, on various types of process improvements within the membrane structure, so we have some very good projects on the book. I wouldn’t want to get into any more detail on them right now though.

componenttext: First question is just on the Life Sciences side. It looks like you've put up a quarter with record operating margin. Is this the type of operating margin that you think we're going to be able to expect going forward here or is it going to level off or get better, and how do you view the next few quarters in this segment?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We would expect that Life Sciences operating margins may dip a little bit as couple of things happened also in Life Sciences. Between Food and Beverage and BioPharm we do expect to see a ramp up of systems. I will add that Life Science's gross margins and
componenttext: We would expect that Life Sciences operating margins may dip a little bit as couple of things happened also in Life Sciences. Between Food and Beverage and BioPharm we do expect to see a ramp up of systems. I will add that Life Science's gross margins and operating margins have seen a little bit of pressure from the weakening of the euro - the euro for us against two key currencies, the pound and the dollar against last year and going into the year. So we felt a little bit of pressure in this quarter year-over-year and depending upon what the euro does, that may put some pressure as well.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Then just one other question for Lisa. Going back to your five year plan and the recent goals that you've put out. I think that your long term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25ish% range and can you update us on couple of initiatives over the
componenttext: Then just one other question for Lisa. Going back to your five year plan and the recent goals that you've put out. I think that your long term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25ish% range and can you update us on couple of initiatives over the next couple of years that are going to get you there and whether those are on track and if we can still expect that type of tax rate eventually?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the first initiative which is look out us from 31% to 27% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we are working on this year that would go, that you would see come to fruit
componenttext: Well, the first initiative which is look out us from 31% to 27% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we are working on this year that would go, that you would see come to fruition and the financial results in fiscal year 2012 is doing something similar with our industrial leadership for Europe, centralizing that into Switzerland. Then the last key leg of that tax forecast is Asia and we are centralizing our Asian leadership into Singapore until - both Switzerland and Singapore are both places that we've negotiated favorable tax position. In both places, we're putting our leadership, managing our supply chain demand planning and we're on track with all of those things. So, working quite diligently through fiscal year '11 to see it come into effect in 2012.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to Pall Corporation's Conference Call and Webcast for their first quarter for fiscal 2011. [Operator Instructions] We would like to remind you that the company's first quarter release is available at www.pall.com. Management's remarks this morni
componenttext:
Welcome to Pall Corporation's Conference Call and Webcast for their first quarter for fiscal 2011. [Operator Instructions] We would like to remind you that the company's first quarter release is available at www.pall.com. 
Management's remarks this morning will include forward-looking statements. Please refer to Slide 2 or request a copy of the specific wording of this qualification of the company's remarks. 
Management also uses certain non-GAAP measures to assess the company's performance. Reconciliations of these measures to their GAAP counterparts are included in the slides at the end of the presentation.
At this time, I will turn the call over to Mr. Eric Krasnoff, Pall Corporation's Chairman, CEO and President. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here to review Pall's first quarter results with you. Thanks for joining us. I'm here this morning with Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Controller.Lisa and I will review
componenttext:
Good morning. It's a pleasure to be here to review Pall's first quarter results with you. Thanks for joining us. I'm here this morning with Lisa McDermott, our Chief Financial Officer; and Frank Moschella, our Corporate Controller.
Lisa and I will review some of the details and drivers of the quarter, and following that, we look forward to your questions. The first quarter provided a good start to the year. Sales were $605 million, a 12% increase in local currency. Negative exchange rates reduced this by 1.5%. Revenues increased by double digits in both businesses with sales growth broad-based by market and geography.
Overall orders increased 7%, with consumables growing just over 8%, and the backlog is up over 20% in both consumables and systems. Life Sciences continued to perform well. The top line grew over 10% and margins improved. The lead story this quarter is the reemergence of Industrial. Sales grew 14% with healthy contribution from just about every sector. 
Industrial’s gross margins jumped 300 basis points to 47.2%. Operating profit almost doubled from a year ago. 
On a geographic basis, sales grew in both Industrial and Life Sciences in all regions. The Western Hemisphere grew over 25% led by Industrial with sales increased 39%. Europe and Asia grew 5% and 8%, respectively. The emerging regions we've been focusing on, including Latin America, MENA, China, India and Southeast Asia, which represent about 20% of total sales, grew over 20% as well. The strong top line, coupled with Pall's deeply ingrained productivity improvement culture, drove gross margins up to 51% and operating margins over 17%. This is a significant achievement.
With that, let's look at the details, starting with Life Sciences. BioPharmaceuticals, which represents about 25% of Pall's total sales, had another strong quarter. Revenues increased about 15%, with Pharmaceuticals and Laboratory growing at similar rates. 
Consumable sales were up almost 14%, and system sales increased 30%. The biotech and plasma markets remain strong, while the vaccine market was flat even without a separate vaccine for H1N1 this year. Demand for Pall's single-use technologies also continues to drive growth. 
All regions advanced, with the Western Hemisphere and Asia particularly robust, at about 25% growth each. Sales in Europe grew 5%. Sales in the emerging regions while small are growing quickly, driven by increasing demand and higher level of standards for medical care. Orders remained strong in BioPharmaceuticals with bookings for Pharma consumables up over 25%.
Medical also had a good quarter, with sales up 5% in all regions contributing. Blood Filtration sales grew slightly despite modest reductions in blood collections in the Western Hemisphere. The OEM submarket grew 19%. This reflects increased medical device production in new business for our proprietary materials. The hospital critical care market also grew slightly. Cell therapy, a small revenue base today but exciting for the future, continued to grow by double digits.
Sales in Food and Beverage grew almost 9%. Let's note, however, this comparison of Q1 is the lowest point in fiscal 2010 where Food and Beverage sales dropped 18%. All regions have now returned to positive territory, led by the Western Hemisphere at 25% and Asia at 14%. 
Europe, the largest part of the Food and Beverage market for Pall, grew with 4% as the region continues to recover. Consumable sales grew over 11%, reflecting increased production and the success of Pall's system strategy. There are now about 800 Pall's systems for cold beer filtration and wine clarification in the field. And we are currently working on the biggest pipeline of systems projects in several years.
Pending legislation currently awaiting House approval could provide an additional boost to Pall's Food and Beverage business over time. The U.S. Senate recently approved the biggest overhaul to the nation's food safety laws since the 1930s. The bill places this greater responsibility on manufacturers and farmers to prevent contamination during production. The bill also gives vast new powers to the FDA, which recognizes the role of filtration and preventing contamination, and a benefit of process monitoring to ensure quality before final QC.
Now let's move on to Industrial which had quite a good quarter. Sales overall increased 14%. Aeropower came back strong at 24% growth, and two of the three Energy & Water submarkets grew double digits. Yet we still saw a weakness in capital spending in the larger Fuels and Chemicals submarket. Microelectronics grew over 29%. 
So let's look at the details starting with Aeropower, which grew 24% in Q1. Machinery & Equipment posted double-digit growth for the third quarter in a row. This time, increasing 32%. Sales almost doubled in the Western Hemisphere, increased about 15% in Europe and almost 19% in Asia. The global mining in primary metals markets are in high gear. Q1 orders were also strong. Aerospace grew over 15% after four quarters of double-digit declines. Both submarkets in all regions contributed. 
Military Aerospace, up 6%, was driven by Western Hemisphere demand and -- which was up 10%. Shipments were for multiple military programs, including the Joint Strike Fighter, as well as spares for the U.S. government.
Despite the lack of CH-47 orders, which we had expected, we are maintaining our full year outlook for aerospace as other opportunities fill in the gaps. Commercial Aerospace made a nice comeback in the quarter with 27% growth on contributions from all regions. This reflects some inventory restocking by Pall distributors to the airline, as well as a modest increase in aircraft build rates. 
With Energy & Water, Municipal Water and Power Generation performing well within the quarter, we saw 11% growth each. Fuels and Chemicals was down 13%, reflecting the hangover effect of scant capital orders during the economic downturn. This was exacerbated by challenging comps from some very large systems orders that shipped a year ago. 
Importantly, increased activity in the sector showed true with consumable sales increasing by over 10%. This was the second quarter in a row of consumables growth after four quarters of double-digit declines.  This was driven by the Western Hemisphere with 35% growth and Europe at 17%, and reflects increased production of oil, gas, chemicals and polymers. 
Power Generation saw a strong growth in the Western Hemisphere and Asia. Key drivers there were water treatment systems for U.S. power generation stations and continued expansion of the wind turbine market in China. Europe remained weak through the ongoing challenges in the turbomachinery market and from reduced demand for power tied industrial production. 
Municipal Water sales grew 11% in the quarter with the Western Hemisphere up 25%. The U.S. market remained strong, as municipalities continue to upgrade to membrane filtration to comply with EPA water quality standards.
Europe has been weak, but orders for the last two quarters increased double digits. The backlog is up to $115 million in Municipal Water, which is a 25% increase over last year. So overall, we have a mixed bag in Energy & Water both by market and region. The Energy & Water markets were not hit as hard as many of the other industrial markets nor were they bouncing back as quickly. 
And finally, save the best for last, Microelectronics. Microelectronics remained strong in the opening quarter, with sales up over 29%. All regions and key customer markets grew, while continues to reflect high utilization rate of chip producers and healthy consumer demand for advanced Microelectronics, such as LED display technology. We do not expect this rate of growth to continue, as production catches up with underlying demand and the comps get tougher. The flat panel display market may slow down due to well-publicized oversupply, but that was not our Q1 experience.
Orders, which have been up sharply for four quarters, this time, increased 22%. In any case, we continue to expect a good year from Microelectronics. 
Now with that, Lisa McDermott will review the financial details. Lisa?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter. Net earnings in the quarter were $71.4 million or $0.61 per share compared to $67 million or $0.56 per share last year. Pro forma earnings per
componenttext:
Thank you, Eric. Good morning, everyone. I'll begin with a recap of Pall's financial results for the quarter. Net earnings in the quarter were $71.4 million or $0.61 per share compared to $67 million or $0.56 per share last year. 
Pro forma earnings per share as defined on Slide 18 was $0.62 compared to $0.40 per share, an increase of 55%. Foreign currency translation had no material impact on earnings per share in the quarter. 
Quarter one sales increased by 10.7%, foreign currency translation decreased the top line by about $8 million or 1.4%. This was primarily due to the strengthening of the U.S. dollar against the euro, British pound and Korean won, partly offset by the weakening of the U.S. dollar against the Japanese yen and Australian dollar.
Excluding this impact, sales were up 12.1% compared to the first quarter of fiscal year '10, reflecting a 13.6% increase in consumable sales, with contributions from both Life Sciences and Industrial. System sales were essentially flat, as double-digit growth in Life Sciences was offset by a mid-single-digit decline in Industrial. Pricing gains in Life Sciences and Industrial contributed approximately $3.2 million to the top line. 
For the full year, we expect local currency sales growth of mid- to high-single digits in both Life Sciences and Industrial. The outlook for some markets has improved a bit since the beginning of the fiscal year. It now looks like medical could grow low to mid-single digits for the year. And BioPharmaceuticals is off to a strong start, and our original high single-digit outlook now looks like it could be slightly conservative. 
Our outlook for Food and Beverage still permits single-digit growth. Aeropower may also have a better year than we originally expected. We now believe Aeropower can deliver high single to low double-digit sales growth, with Machinery & Equipment growing by high single to low double-digit, and aerospace growing by low double-digit. 
Our outlook for Energy & Water is unchanged. We continue to expect the Energy market to grow at mid-single digits, and water, which will be primarily systems, to grow double digits, for overall growth in the Energy & Water market of mid-single digits.
Finally, we continue to expect Microelectronics growth to stabilize at high single digits for the year. This contemplates maintaining sales at levels similar to this quarter throughout the fiscal year. 
Gross margin in the first quarter improved 160 basis points compared to last year to 51% with contributions from both businesses. Sequentially, gross margins improved by 120 basis points and this principally reflects the change in mix from the fourth quarter of 2010 when systems comprised 15% of sales versus about 9% in the first quarter. 
Pall Industrial's gross margins came in at 47.2%, up 300 basis points compared to last year, as Eric mentioned.  The improvement in margins was primarily due to continued improvement in factory utilization and overhead absorption driven by volume growth. Also, the estimated benefit of cost-saving initiatives, including improved efficiency and manufacturing operations, outpaced inflation.
Life Sciences gross margins also increased, coming in at 54.5%, up 40 basis points. This reflects continued pricing improvement, and the benefit of sales channel changes, as well as manufacturing cost reductions on a net basis. We continue to project gross margins for the full year to be in a range of 50% to 51%. Pricing, volume and continued manufacturing efficiency should be partly offset by mix headwinds as system sales surge in the latter part of the year, and lower margin markets continued to recover.
SG&A was 30.1% of sales in the first quarter, down from 32.3% in the comparable quarter. SG&A expense increased 4.7%, excluding the estimated impact of foreign exchange. Approximately 60% of this increase relates to investments we're making to drive sales up and SG&A down in the future. These include the cost of building up our European and Asian headquarters, the implementation of our global ERP system and the investments in emerging regions, such as MENA where we opened our new office in Dubai in this past quarter. The remainder is attributable to inflationary items. 
Our improved revenue outlook combined with some spending deferred until later in the year, which reduces the fiscal year's spend, should result in full year SG&A as a percentage of sales at or below 30%. R&D spending rose about 17%, and we expect it will be just under 3.5% of sales for the year.
Turning to income taxes, the effective tax rate or as reported rate for the quarter, was 26.8% as compared to 10.5% in the first quarter of fiscal year 2010. Excluding the benefit from the favorable resolution of foreign tax audits during the first quarter of last year, this represents a sustainable reduction year-over-year and a tax rate of about 4% as forecasted. The reduction has contributed about $4 million to the bottom line so far. The full year forecasted rate of about 27% reflects the tax benefits associated with the establishment of our European headquarters.
Net interest expense in the first quarter of last year reflects the benefit of reversing accrued interest of approximately $9 million, primarily related to the resolution of this foreign tax audit. Excluding this item, net interest expense increased by approximately $1 million driven by an increase in debt levels compared to the same period of last year. 
Earlier this week, we issued $205 million of commercial paper at just about 1.2%, including support costs. This is about 1% lower than the borrowings under our revolver, which are being repaid with the proceeds from the commercial paper issuance. 
Turning now to cash flow. Operating cash flow in the quarter was $58.7 million compared to $73 million last year, a decrease from $14.5 million or about 20%. This reflects an increase in certain payments tied to fiscal 2010 earnings performance, which was considerably stronger than 2009, such as income taxes and variable-based compensation. This was partially offset by continued improvement in working capital management.
Significant uses of cash during the quarter included $62 million return to shareholders, with dividends of $37 million and $25 million to repurchase approximately 580,000 shares of the company's common stock. And this leaves approximately $328 million of our current authorization, $25 million in capital spending and $17 million in repayments of debt, net of new borrowing. Our cash position stood at $479 million at October 31, and our net debt to net debt plus equity was 18.7%, down from 19.4% at the end of fiscal year 2010.
For the full year, we expect operating cash flows to be in the range of $435 million to $460 million, and capital expenditures to be in the range of $165 million to $175 million. 
Now as Eric said, this quarter provided a good start to the year. We see the successful execution on key initiatives clearly showing through in our results from the top to the bottom line. Based upon the first quarter results and outlook, we now expect projected pro forma EPS to be in the range of $2.48 to $2.63 for fiscal 2011. This reflects the neutral impact from foreign currency translation compared to last year to earnings per share based upon where our current rate stands, including the euro-U.S. exchange rate of $1.3 for the last nine months. 
Thank you for your attention this morning. With that, I will hand this back to Eric.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, Lisa. Our increased EPS guidance is grounded by what we have seen for the first four months of the year and the market outlook that Lisa shared with us this morning. You should note that our updated outlook provides some cautions that
componenttext:
Thank you very much, Lisa. Our increased EPS guidance is grounded by what we have seen for the first four months of the year and the market outlook that Lisa shared with us this morning. You should note that our updated outlook provides some cautions that the year-over-year EPS growth is expected to lessen as we move through fiscal 2011. The first quarter included inventory replenishments. 
One major variable in our guidance is Microelectronics. Our forward visibility in this highly cyclical market is only about three months. We are currently projecting Microelectronics revenue to show no growth in the second half of the year. We'll see. 
Now we've covered a lot of ground this morning and appreciate your patience. Now with the help of the conference operator, we are ready for your questions.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

componenttext: I want to follow up on sort of what you were alluding to at the end, and maybe giving us a little more insight on -- you started off with such a strong first quarter. The dynamics you see in the second, should we be expecting sort of normalized seasonal sequential progressions? Or is there very specific guidance that may be a delta from typical?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we've given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year, that our expectations on earnings growth are 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter. Looking at the seco
componenttext: What I would say qualitatively is, and in light of the guidance that we've given, that just speaking broadly about the balance of the year, that our expectations on earnings growth are 15% to 20%-ish, not the 55% we saw in the quarter. Looking at the second quarter, there are some areas where we may not see growth quite a strong as in the first quarter in areas such as Aeropower and a couple of the other Industrial areas. So typically, we, our revenues increased sequentially throughout the year, and that may not be the case Q2 to Q1.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Eric, as a follow-up on that, you mentioned some specific -- in MicroE you have a short view, a shorter-term view. We're obviously in the volatile season for that with the holidays and New Year's and post-Christmas changeovers and the like. Any insigh
componenttext: And Eric, as a follow-up on that, you mentioned some specific -- in MicroE you have a short view, a shorter-term view. We're obviously in the volatile season for that with the holidays and New Year's and post-Christmas changeovers and the like. Any insight at least as to your expectation or what the customer base is -- could you give me a feedback on at the moment?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor chip IC driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductors side, what we'
componenttext: What we're expecting in our market now is probably 50-50 between consumer electronics driven and semiconductor chip IC driven sales. We expect that consumer electronics will continue to be stronger throughout the year. On the semiconductors side, what we're hearing is that there's going to be a retrenchment in capital spend, but not in the basic rate of chip production, which would mean for us a slowing or flattening perhaps of growth in the second half of the year, but also an improvement in the product mix as, if the consumables side stays stronger.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Dane in for Jon. Just a quick question on the system sales. From the commentary, there is the expectation that there is just going to be a surge in the back half of this fiscal year. Maybe you could just kind of parse out some details and
componenttext: This is actually Dane in for Jon. Just a quick question on the system sales. From the commentary, there is the expectation that there is just going to be a surge in the back half of this fiscal year. Maybe you could just kind of parse out some details and kind of like, based on current forecast, what kind of percentage of sales that could get up to? Are we thinking that maybe that could get back to like a teens' percentage of total revenue sales? Then kind of maybe just give a little color around, are these orders already in the backlog, or is there an anticipation of orders coming through in the next couple of quarters here that may be realized around the fourth quarter timeframe?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third a
componenttext: So looking at the back nine months of the year, we would expect our systems revenues as a percentage of our total revenues to be about 15% of sales compared to say, the 9% that we saw in the first quarter, and clearly escalating as we get into the third and fourth quarter, up to say, 18% to 20% of sales in say, the fourth quarter. In terms of backlog, a substantial or say, lion's share of what we're forecasting for systems revenue for the year is pretty much in the backlog. There is some that we're still expecting. And we expect that, that should happen by the end of this month into the end of January.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And kind of what sub-segments is the majority -- I know in the past you mentioned kind of Muni Water is being some of these larger systems sales. Any other segments that we should be thinking about?
componenttext: And kind of what sub-segments is the majority -- I know in the past you mentioned kind of Muni Water is being some of these larger systems sales. Any other segments that we should be thinking about?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: The sectors in addition to Muni Water that you would be thinking about are clearly Energy and Aeropower, and Food and Beverage.
componenttext: The sectors in addition to Muni Water that you would be thinking about are clearly Energy and Aeropower, and Food and Beverage.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Chris Parkinson on behalf of Hamzah. Could you just talk a little more about how pricing is currently trending and how aggressive you believe you're being relative to your competitors in the marketplace, please?
componenttext: This is Chris Parkinson on behalf of Hamzah. Could you just talk a little more about how pricing is currently trending and how aggressive you believe you're being relative to your competitors in the marketplace, please?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Actually, we can't comment on our competitors' pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side. And that's been the trend for the last couple of yea
componenttext: Actually, we can't comment on our competitors' pricing. We are, of course, continuing to push for price increases and we're getting more price increase on the Life Science side than the Industrial side. And that's been the trend for the last couple of years I think because of the macroeconomics. We expect that the economy now is recovering and has much more robust demand on Industrial, we'll be seeing better price increasing as we go into the last three quarters of this year. We're targeting 1%, basically, maybe a bit over that, as a reasonable expectation for the year. Pall is, in many of our markets, we have one or two major competitors and we are very disciplined, and believe that we are a leader in price.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick follow-up, could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business? And basically, what type of incremental margins are you currently seeing and how much further our cost takeout has been left on the horizon?
componenttext: And just a quick follow-up, could you frame for us your current operating leverage inherent in your business? And basically, what type of incremental margins are you currently seeing and how much further our cost takeout has been left on the horizon?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the current, at the operating margin level, we're see incremental margins of 40% to 50%, in general. And clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix, very strong consumables quarter, and markets like Pharma and Microelectronics and
componenttext: Well, the current, at the operating margin level, we're see incremental margins of 40% to 50%, in general. And clearly, that's a function in addition to the volume, the mix, very strong consumables quarter, and markets like Pharma and Microelectronics and M&E driving a very, very strong incremental margin. As we progress throughout the year, we would expect to start to see that certainly come down as systems sales and lower-margin markets make up a higher preponderance of our book of business.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Wood with Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jon Wood with Jefferies.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Lisa, just to follow up on that last question, the last update, I think, you guys provided was 25% to 30% contribution margin on the systems. Has that changed at all over the last couple of quarters?
componenttext: Lisa, just to follow up on that last question, the last update, I think, you guys provided was 25% to 30% contribution margin on the systems. Has that changed at all over the last couple of quarters?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: It actually changed a bit in the first quarter. And by the way, that was gross margin as opposed to contribution margin. In our first quarter, we did have some pretty good margin, gross margins on systems' unique quarter relative to some water trailers. S
componenttext: It actually changed a bit in the first quarter. And by the way, that was gross margin as opposed to contribution margin. In our first quarter, we did have some pretty good margin, gross margins on systems' unique quarter relative to some water trailers. So that did add a bit to gross margin in this quarter in addition to the fact that systems sales were light in the quarter. We don't necessarily expect to see that continuing. We expect that we would be back into the 25% to 30% gross margin range for the book of systems in the back part of the year.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the reason it wouldn't continue is just a function of mix, the type of systems being shipped?
componenttext: And the reason it wouldn't continue is just a function of mix, the type of systems being shipped?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

componenttext: On the R&D, it seems like that's ticked up quite a bit, and you're saying you have 3.5%, or so percent for the year. Is there anything you can comment on in terms of projects you're accelerating or anything different you're doing? I'm not sure...

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we've revamped the R&D structure. We have a Chief Technology Officer now. I think we put out a press release. And under him, we pulled from the various lines of business a core research group. And with that, we are focusing again on diagnostics, on t
componenttext: Yes, we've revamped the R&D structure. We have a Chief Technology Officer now. I think we put out a press release. And under him, we pulled from the various lines of business a core research group. And with that, we are focusing again on diagnostics, on the various types of process improvements within the membrane structures. So we have some very good projects on the book. I wouldn't want to get into a more detail on them right now though.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: So it's a safe assumption that going forward, R&D continues to tick up as a percent of sales?
componenttext: So it's a safe assumption that going forward, R&D continues to tick up as a percent of sales?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, but not to the degree we saw in the first quarter.
componenttext: Yes, but not to the degree we saw in the first quarter.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then last one on, Lisa, $25 million in buyback in the quarter, right on your pace over the past five or so. Can you just comment on anything that would change that pacing in the balance of 2011?
componenttext: And then last one on, Lisa, $25 million in buyback in the quarter, right on your pace over the past five or so. Can you just comment on anything that would change that pacing in the balance of 2011?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that the only possible thing that could change that pacing would be a higher-priority capital allocation item strategically. Absent that, I think you can expect from Pall, what you've seen from Pall for quite sometime now.
componenttext: I would say that the only possible thing that could change that pacing would be a higher-priority capital allocation item strategically. Absent that, I think you can expect from Pall, what you've seen from Pall for quite sometime now.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Drab with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Drab with William Blair.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: First question is just on the Life Sciences side, looks like I think you've put up a quarter with record operating margin. And is this the type of operating margin that you think we're going to be able to expect going forward here? Or is it going to level
componenttext: First question is just on the Life Sciences side, looks like I think you've put up a quarter with record operating margin. And is this the type of operating margin that you think we're going to be able to expect going forward here? Or is it going to level off or get better? And how do you view the next few quarters in this segment?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: We would expect that Life Sciences margins may -- operating margins may dip a little bit as couple of things happen. Also in Life Sciences, between Food and Beverage and BioPharma, we do expect to see a ramp-up of systems. And I will add that Life Science
componenttext: We would expect that Life Sciences margins may -- operating margins may dip a little bit as couple of things happen. Also in Life Sciences, between Food and Beverage and BioPharma, we do expect to see a ramp-up of systems. And I will add that Life Sciences' gross margins and operating margins have seen a little bit of pressure from the weakening of the euro against -- the euro for us against two key currencies, the pound and the dollar, so against last year and going into the year, so we saw a little bit of pressure in this quarter year-over-year and depending upon what the euro does, that may put some pressure as well.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then, just one other question for Lisa, going back to your five-year plan and the recent goals that you put out, I think that you're long-term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25-ish percent range. And can you update us on couple of your in
componenttext: And then, just one other question for Lisa, going back to your five-year plan and the recent goals that you put out, I think that you're long-term goal for the tax rate is to get down to the 25-ish percent range. And can you update us on couple of your initiatives over the next couple of years that are going to get you there and whether those are on track and if we can still expect that type of tax rate eventually?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, the first initiative, which is what got us from 31-ish% to 27-ish% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we're working on this year that would go -- that we would se
componenttext: Sure. Well, the first initiative, which is what got us from 31-ish% to 27-ish% this year was the centralization of our Life Sciences leadership into Switzerland. The second part of that now that we're working on this year that would go -- that we would see come to fruition in the financial results in fiscal year 2012 is doing something similar with our Industrial leadership for Europe, centralizing that into Switzerland. And then, the last key leg of that tax forecast is Asia. And we are centralizing our Asian leadership into Singapore. And so, both Switzerland and Singapore are both places that we've negotiated favorable tax position. And in both places, we're putting our leadership managing our supply chain, demand planning. And we're on track with all those things, so working quite diligently through fiscal year '11 to see it come into effect in 2012.

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Rose with Wedbush Morgan Securities.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Rose with Wedbush Morgan Securities.

componenttext: I was hoping you could break down your expectations of SG&A in the fourth quarter, what you need to see in the fourth quarter versus the fourth quarter a year ago to get to the same sort of numbers. Is it possible? And what do you have to do?

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010

componenttext: Do you mean in terms of dollars or do you mean...

headline: Pall Corp., Q1 2011 Earnings Call, Dec 10, 2010
